By parametrizing this new distribution as another flow model, they can efficiently train it using variational inference and also handle conditioning under arbitrary differentiable transformations.

This paper proposes a large - scale Electron Microscopy ( EM ) dataset, U - RISC, for cell membrane segmentation. It is the largest annotated EM dataset for the Cell membrane with multiple iterative annotations and uncompressed high - resolution raw data. The authors claim that the current popular segmentation evaluation criteria are inconsistent with human perception. They propose a new evaluation criterion called Perceptual Hausdorff Distance ( PHD ) to measure the quality of cell membranes segmentation results.

This paper proposes a new benchmark for continual learning ( CL ) in which the learner is trained on a sequence of tasks, and the goal is to learn to perform a given task. The authors propose a new modular architecture, whose modules represent atomic skills that can be composed to solve a certain task. They propose a learning algorithm that leverages a task - driven prior over the exponential search space of all possible ways to combine modules, enabling efficient learning on long streams of tasks. The experiments show that this modular architecture and learning algorithm perform competitively on widely used CL benchmarks.

This paper proposes a generative model - based unsupervised meta - learning approach for few - shot classification tasks. The proposed method generates pairs of in - class and out - of - class samples from the latent space in a principled way, allowing us to create synthetic classes forming the training and validation data of a meta - task. The experimental results show that the proposed approach, LAtent Space Interpolation Unsupervised Meta - learning ( LASIUM ), outperforms or is competitive with current un - supervised learning baselines on few - shots classification tasks on the most widely used benchmark datasets.

This paper studies the injectivity of fully connected and convolutional ReLU layers and networks. The authors show that an expansivity factor of two is necessary and sufficient for injectivity by constructing appropriate weight matrices. They show that global injectivity with iid Gaussian matrices requires larger expansivity between 3.4 and 10.5. They also characterize the stability of inverting an injective network via worst - case Lipschitz constants of the inverse.

This paper proposes the continuous conditional generative adversarial network ( CcGAN ), the first generative model for image generation conditional on continuous, scalar conditions ( regression labels ). The authors propose two new empirical discriminator losses ( HVDL and SVDL ), a novel empirical generator loss and a novel label input method are proposed to overcome the two problems of existing conditional GANs. Experiments are conducted on the Circular 2 - D Gaussians, RC-49, and UTKFace datasets. The proposed method is able to generate diverse, high - quality samples from the image distribution conditional on a given regression label.

This paper proposes an active learning ( AL ) - based method to reduce the sample complexity of supervised learning ( SSL ) by querying unlabeled instances to be annotated by a human - in - the - loop. The authors argue that the annotation efficiency brought by AL algorithms that seek diversity on labeled samples can be improved upon when using SSL as the training scheme. In particular, the authors propose an AL algorithm that focuses on controlling the convergence rate of a classification network by actively querying instances to improve the rate of convergence upon inclusion to the labeled set.

The paper proposes FedDyn, a federated learning method for training neural networks. The proposed method is based on exact minimization, where at each round, each participating device updates its regularizer so that the optimal model for the regularized loss is in conformity with the global empirical loss. Empirical results show that the proposed method leads to efficient training in both convex and non - convex settings, while being fully agnostic to device heterogeneity and robust to large number of devices.

This paper proposes a method to accelerate the training of self - supervised learning algorithms based on contrastive loss. The main idea is to truncate the backpropagation and update only a part of the parameters for each gradient descent update. The proposed method is evaluated on ImageNet linear classification, PASCAL VOC object detection and segmentation. The authors show that their method can save the training time with almost no loss on the final performance of the downstream tasks.

This paper studies the global convergence and global optimality of actor - critic in the single - time setting, where the actor and critic are updated simultaneously. In particular, the critic update is obtained by applying the Bellman evaluation operator only once while the actor is updated in the policy gradient direction computed using the critic. The authors show that the actor sequence converges to a globally optimal policy at a sublinear O(K−1/2 ) rate, where K is the number of iterations.

This paper proposes to represent log data at three levels of abstraction : field level, log level, and log sequence level. The field level representation is in vector format and serves as interfaces to downstream applications. The log sequence representation can be computed from the previous level. This paper proposes a transformer network to encode numerical and textual information that is suitable for log embeddings. The authors show how a number of log processing applications can be readily solved with their representation.

This paper presents a method for decomposing convolutional layers of CNNs into a sequence of wavelet decompositions, which are modulated by freely - trained mixture weights. The method is motivated by the similarities between trained CNN kernels and oriented Gabor filters for addressing this problem. The proposed method is evaluated with three variants of the AlexNet architecture for image classification. The first variant relies on the separable wavelet packet transform while the other two implement the 2D dual - tree real and complex wavelet packets.

This paper proposes a coach - player framework for multi - agent reinforcement learning. In this framework, the players have a partial view of the environment, while the coach has a complete view. The coach coordinates the players by distributing individual strategies. The authors propose an attention mechanism for both the players and the coach and incorporate a variational objective to regularize learning. They also design an adaptive communication method to let the coach decide when to communicate with different players.

This paper provides a comprehensive and large - scale empirical study of successes and failures of influence functions in neural network models trained on datasets such as Iris, MNIST, CIFAR-10 and ImageNet. Through extensive experiments, the authors show that the network architecture, its depth and width, as well as the extent of model parameterization and regularization techniques have strong effects in the accuracy of influence function estimates. In particular, they find that ( i ) influence estimates are fairly accurate for shallow networks, while for deeper networks the estimates are often erroneous ; ( ii ) for certain network architectures and datasets, training with weight - decay regularization is important to get high - quality influence estimates ; and ( iii ) the accuracy can vary significantly depending on the examined test points.

This paper studies the connection between next word prediction and text classification. The authors propose to reformulate the classification tasks of interest as sentence completion tasks, thus making language modeling a meaningful pretraining task. They show that language models that are - optimal in cross - entropy ( log - complexity ) learn features that can linearly solve such classification tasks with O(\sqrt(\epsilon ) ) error, thus demonstrating that doing well on language modeling can be beneficial for downstream tasks. They also propose a new objective function that performs well on some classification tasks.

This paper proposes a new method for membership inference attacks ( MIA ). The proposed method is based on a novel difficulty score that can be computed for each image, and its computation does not require a training set. The method is evaluated on a number of benchmarks and is shown to achieve high MIA accuracy.

This paper proposes a differentiable architecture search method by formulating the architecture mixing weight as random variables, modeled by Dirichlet distribution. This formulation improves the generalization ability and induces stochasticity that naturally encourages exploration in the search space. To alleviate the large memory consumption of differentiable NAS, the authors propose a simple yet effective progressive learning scheme that enables searching directly on large - scale tasks, eliminating the gap between search and evaluation phases. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of the method.

This paper proposes a new method for function approximators for low - dimensional but complex functions. The proposed method is based on multiplicative filter networks, which simply multiply together ( linear functions of ) sinusoidal or Gabor wavelet functions applied to the input. This representation has the notable advantage that the entire function can simply be viewed as a linear approximator over an exponential number of Fourier or Gabors basis functions, respectively.

This paper proposes a teacher - student scheme to enable gradient - based meta - learning algorithms to explore long horizons by the inner loop. The key idea is to employ a student network to adequately explore the search space of task - specific models ( e.g., by more than ten steps ), and a teacher then takes a “ leap ” toward the regions probed by the student. The teacher not only arrives at a high - quality model but also defines a lightweight computation graph for meta - gradients. The proposed method is evaluated on several tasks, including few - shot learning, long - tail recognition, and meta - attack.

This paper proposes a new algorithm for offline reinforcement learning based on behavior regularization. The authors propose to use an analytical upper bound on KL divergence as the behavior regularizor to reduce variance associated with sample based estimations. They also propose a gradient penalty term to the policy evaluation objective to penalize the gradient of the Q value w.r.t the out - of - distribution actions. The proposed algorithm outperforms existing model - free and model - based offline RL algorithms in various datasets.

This paper proposes a new training method for CNN - based neural networks. The proposed method trains both the original and the smaller networks together, where the parameters of the smaller network are shared across both the architectures. The authors provide theoretical guarantees on the regularization behavior of the adjoint training paradigm. Empirical evaluation on CIFAR-100 and Imagenet shows that the proposed method can achieve a 99.7x reduction in the number of parameters and a 5x improvement in inference time.

This paper proposes a simple extension of greedy exploration in reinforcement learning ( RL ). The authors argue that the main limitation of greedy is its lack of temporal persistence, which limits its ability to escape local optima. They propose a temporally extended form of greedy that simply repeats the sampled action for a random duration. They show that, for many duration distributions, this suffices to improve exploration on a large set of domains.

This paper studies the implicit regularization of gradient flow with infinitesimal initialization in the matrix factorization problem. In particular, the authors show that for depth - 2 matrix factorisation, gradient flow is equivalent to Greedy Low - Rank Learning ( GLRL ) under some reasonable assumptions. This generalizes the rank minimization view from previous works to a much broader setting and enables us to construct counter - examples to refute the conjecture from Gunasekar et al. ( 2017 ). The authors also extend the results to the case where depth > 3 and show that the benefit of being deeper is that the above convergence has a much weaker dependence over initialization magnitude.

This paper proposes a method for model patching to improve the robustness of a classifier. The proposed method is based on two stages : first, it models subgroup features within a class and learns semantic transformations between them, and then trains the classifier with data augmentations that deliberately manipulate sub group features. Experiments are conducted on three benchmark datasets to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new classifier, named Rule - based Representation Learner ( RRL ), that automatically learns interpretable nonfuzzy rules for data representation. To train the non - differentiable RRL effectively, the authors project it to a continuous space and propose a novel training method, called Gradient Grafting, that can directly optimize the discrete model using gradient descent. An improved design of logical activation functions is also devised to increase the scalability of RRL and enable it to discretize the continuous features end - to - end.

This paper proposes a new regret minimization algorithm to tackle the problem of generalization across structured biomedical domains such as molecular scaffolds or protein families. In particular, the authors propose a representation that enables the predictor to compete against an oracle with hindsight access to unseen domains. The proposed method is evaluated on three real - world biomedical tasks : molecular property prediction, protein homology and stability prediction and show that it outperforms previous state - of - the - art baselines.

This paper proposes a novel architecture, cross - probe BERT, to improve the performance of text - vision BERT models. The proposed method is based on the two - tower architecture, where the image is concatenated with the local features and the query ’s word features, and the image and the word features are combined to generate the attended vision probes and the attended text probes, respectively.   The proposed approach is evaluated on two public datasets, and it is shown to be more efficient than the baseline BERT.

This paper proposes a new type of Actor, named forward - looking Actor ( FORK ), for Actor - Critic algorithms. The proposed method can be easily integrated into a model - free ActorCritic algorithm. Experiments on six Box2D and MuJoCo environments with continuous state and action spaces demonstrate significant performance improvement FORK can bring to the state - of - the - art algorithms.

This paper proposes a Bayesian model ensemble method for federated learning. The proposed method is based on Bayesian inference. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms FEDAVG on CIFAR-10/100 and Tiny - ImageNet under different client conditions ( i.e., i.i.d. and non - i.d. ones ). They also show that it is compatible with recent efforts in regularizing users ’ model training.

This paper presents a method for explaining the contextualization of BERT models under double - blind review. The authors propose to use multi - partite influence patterns to localize a DNN model ’s handling of a concept of interest. They also propose a pattern refinement method to understand how BERT handles subject - verb number agreement and reflexive anaphora.

This paper studies the training of a deep neural network from a control theory perspective. The authors formulate the supervised learning framework as a control problem where weights of the network are control inputs and learning translates into a tracking problem. An analytical formula for finite - time upper bound on settling time is provided a priori under the assumptions of boundedness of input. Finally, the loss function is robust against input perturbations.

This paper proposes to use the mutual information between each learned latent variables and the auxiliary variable to correctly identify informative latent variables. The authors show that the method taken by GIN for informative latent variable selection is not theoretically supported and can be disproved by experiments. They further show the advantage of their method on various downstream tasks including classification, outlier detection and adversarial attack defence on both synthetic and real data.

This paper proposes LiftPool, a new pooling scheme for down - pooling convolutional neural networks. The idea is to decompose a feature map into sub - bands, each of which contains information with different frequencies. The proposed method is invertible, which makes it possible to up - pool the sub - band information. Experiments on image classification and semantic segmentation show that the proposed method outperforms other pooling schemes.

This paper proposes a fast, distance - preserving, binary embedding algorithm to transform a high - dimensional dataset T ⊆ R into binary sequences in the cube {±1}. When T consists of well - spread ( i.e., non - sparse ) vectors, the proposed method applies a stable noise - shaping quantization scheme to Ax where A is a sparse Gaussian random matrix. The authors show that Euclidean distances among the elements of T are approximated by the `1 norm on the images of $ \mathcal{C}$ under a fast linear transformation. The proposed method is both fast and memory efficient.

This paper proposes to use plasticity rules as a proxy for Gradient Descent ( GD ) in order to improve the robustness and generalization of neural networks. In particular, the authors argue that the plasticity rule can be learned by gradient descent on the parameters of the rule parameters. The authors provide both empirical and theoretical evidence for this hypothesis. In the experiments, the proposed method is shown to perform reasonably well ( with no backpropagation ) and converge with fewer updates. Moreover, the classifiers learned using the proposed methods exhibit surprising levels of tolerance to adversarial perturbations.

This paper proposes a new method for visual question generation ( VQG ). The authors propose a novel learning paradigm to generate visual questions with answer - aware and region - reference. In particular, they aim to ask the right visual question with Double Hints textual answers and visual regions of interests, effectively mitigating the existing one - to - many mapping issue. To this end, they develop a simple methodology to self - learn the visual hints without introducing any additional human annotations. The experiments on VQA2.0 and COCO - QA datasets demonstrate that the proposed method can significantly outperform existing state - of - the - art baselines.

This paper studies whether the double descent phenomenon can be avoided by using optimal regularization. Theoretically, they prove that for certain linear regression models with isotropic data distribution, optimally - tuned `2 regularization achieves monotonic test performance as we grow either the sample size or the model size. They also demonstrate empirically that optimally-tuned `2 can mitigate double descent for more general models, including neural networks.

This paper proposes spatial dependency networks ( SDN ) to improve the performance of VAEs. The proposed method is based on a sequential gating - based mechanism that distributes contextual information across 2 - D space. Experiments are conducted on synthetic and real - world datasets to show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new algorithm for off - policy reinforcement learning ( RL ) based on BCQ ( Fujimoto et al., 2018a ). The main contribution of the paper is the introduction of Expect - Max Q - Learning ( EMaQ ), which is a simplified version of the BCQ algorithm by removing the heuristic perturbation network. Empirically, the proposed algorithm outperforms the state - of - the - art in the online and offline RL settings.

This paper proposes a batch selection algorithm for model fairness. The proposed algorithm is based on bilevel optimization, where the inner optimizer is SGD, and the outer optimizer performs adaptive batch selection to improve fairness. It is shown that the proposed algorithm can be implemented with a single - line code change of PyTorch.

This paper studies the bounds on the Lipschitz constant of monotone DEQs, a recently proposed class of impicitlayer networks. The authors show that monDEQs can be bounded as a simple function of the strong monotonicity parameter of the network. They derive simple - yet - tight bounds on both the input - output mapping and the weight - outputs mapping defined by these networks. They show that the bounds are small relative to those for comparable standard DNNs. They also highlight how to use these bounds to develop PAC - Bayes generalization bounds that do not depend on any depth.

This paper proposes a new method for imitation learning and goal - conditioned reinforcement learning. In the imitation learning setting, the authors propose a method to learn to reach a given state by sampling expert states that the agent is currently not likely to visit and using a value - conditioned value - function to guide the agent towards those states. The authors show that the proposed method achieves state - of - the - art results on a common benchmark.    In the goal conditioned setting, they show that their method can circumvent the problem of sparse rewards while addressing hindsight bias in stochastic domains. In imitation learning, they demonstrate that the approach can learn from extremely sparse amounts of expert data.

This paper proposes a new method for multi - task learning. The proposed method is based on variational Bayesian inference. The paper proposes to use Gumbel - softmax priors to condition the prior of each task on related tasks. The method is evaluated on four benchmark datasets and achieves state - of - the - art performance.

This paper proposes a systematic and unified benchmark, Long - Range Arena, specifically focused on evaluating model quality under long - context scenarios. The benchmark is a suite of tasks consisting of sequences ranging from 1K to 16K tokens, encompassing a wide range of data types and modalities such as text, natural, synthetic images, and mathematical expressions requiring similarity, structural, and visual - spatial reasoning. The authors systematically evaluate ten well - established long - range Transformer models ( Reformer, Linformers, Linear Transformers, Sinkhorn Transformers, Performers, Synthesizers, Sparse Transformers, and Longformers ) on their newly proposed benchmark suite.

This paper proposes a new model for code summarization based on the context and structure of source code. The model is trained on multiple programming languages and achieves state - of - the - art performance on all five programming languages considered in this work. The authors show that jointly training on non - parallel data from multiple languages improves results on all individual languages, where the strongest gains are on low - resource languages.

This paper proposes a reinforcement learning approach for audio - visual navigation. The key idea is to learn to set waypoints that are dynamically set and learned end - to - end within the navigation policy, and to store an acoustic memory that provides a structured, spatially grounded record of what the agent has heard as it moves in the environment. The proposed method is evaluated on two datasets of real - world 3D scenes, Replica and Matterport3D. It outperforms the state of the art for AudioGoal navigation by a substantial margin.

This paper studies the problem of Conway's Game of Life, in which the goal is to predict the next n steps of the cellular automaton. The authors show that a small convolutional neural network trained on this task rarely converges to a solution. They also show that the initialization parameters are sensitive to small perturbations, such as a single sign change. Finally, they observe a critical value d0 such that training minimal networks with examples in which cells are alive with probability d0 dramatically increases the chance of convergence to the solution.

This paper proposes a new semi - supervised learning ( SSL ) method based on consistency regularization. The proposed method considers not only the perturbed inputs but also the similarity among the inputs having the same label. The authors introduce a new objective function, dubbed BatchMean Triplet loss, which has the advantage of computational efficiency while taking into account all input samples. The method achieves state - of - the - art performance across many standard SSL benchmarks with a variety of labeled data amounts.

This paper studies the problem of few - shot meta - learning in the context of a sequence of tasks. In particular, the authors consider the variable - shot setting where the data for each new task arrives incrementally. The authors propose a new algorithm that can adapt to variable amounts of data. They show that their algorithm outperforms empirical risk minimization and previous methods on two online image classification problems consisting of sequences of classification tasks and one online regression problem.

This paper presents a series of experiments to test the sensitivity of Transformer representations to several kinds of structure in sentences. Each probe involves swapping words in a sentence and comparing the representations from perturbed sentences against the original. The experiments are conducted with three different perturbations : ( 1 ) random permutations of n - grams of varying width, ( 2 ) swapping two spans which do or do not form a syntactic phrase, ( 3 ) swapping of two adjacent words which do not break apart a phrase, to test sensitivity to local phrase structure.   Results from the three probes collectively suggest that Transformers build sensitivity to larger parts of the sentence along their layers, and that hierarchical phrase structure plays a role in this process.

This paper presents a method for few - shot image synthesis for GANs with minimum computing cost. The authors propose a light - weight GAN structure that gains superior quality on 1024 × 1024 resolution. The model converges from scratch with just a few hours of training on a single RTX-2080 GPU, and has a consistent performance, even with less than 100 training samples.

This paper proposes a novel dual algorithm for neural network bounding. The main idea is to use a small set of dual variables to achieve tightness and a linear separation oracle. The authors show that the proposed method can achieve better bounds than off - the - shelf solvers in only a fraction of their running time.

This paper proposes a method to augment pre - trained language models with concept - centric commonsense knowledge. The authors propose both generative and contrastive objectives for learning common sense from the text, and use them as intermediate self - supervised learning tasks for incrementally pre - training PTLMs ( before task - specific fine - tuning on downstream datasets ). Extensive experimental results show that the proposed method, concept - aware language model ( CALM ), can pack more common sense knowledge into the parameters of a pre -trained text - to - text transformer without relying on external knowledge graphs, yielding better performance on both NLU and NLG tasks.

This paper proposes a method for unsupervised physical object discovery. The proposed method uses both multi - scale pixel cues and physical motion cues to accurately segment observable and partially occluded objects of varying sizes, and infer properties of those objects. The model reliably segments objects on both synthetic and real scenes. The discovered object properties can also be used to reason about physical events.

This paper proposes a method to increase the margins of training samples by moving the decision boundaries of the DNN model far away from the training samples to improve robustness against adversarial attacks. The method is evaluated on six publicly available datasets ( including a COVID - 19 CT image dataset ) under strong 100 - PGD white - box adversarial attack. The results show that the proposed method significantly improved classification accuracy on noisy data while keeping a relatively high accuracy on clean data.

This paper proposes a new method for knowledge distillation. The proposed method is model - agnostic, where intermediate targets are constructed by a model with the same architecture of teacher and trained by approximate mirror descent. Experiments on both image and text datasets show that the proposed method consistently achieves the state - of - the - art performance comparing to all existing knowledge - distillation methods.

This paper proposes a new method for channel pruning of convolutional neural networks ( CNNs ). The proposed method is based on a hyper - structure network ( HSN ) to generate the architecture of the main network, which can be optimized by regular backpropagation and a regularization term to specify the computational resource of the compact network. Extensive experiments on CIFAR-10 and ImageNet demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper presents a method to learn a theorem prover trained without human proofs. The method is based on a simple tf - idf ( term frequency - inverse document frequency ) based lookup in a deep reinforcement learning scenario. Experiments show that the proposed method outperforms baselines trained only on human proofs in terms of test accuracy.

This paper proposes a new method for data augmentation in the latent space. The proposed method is called MODALS ( Modalityagnostic Automated Data Augmentation in Latent Space ), which is able to augment data for any modality in a generic way. The method is tested on text, tabular, time - series, and image data and can be readily integrated with popular deep learning models.

This paper studies the mean field limit of three - layer neural networks in the mean - field regime. The authors show a global convergence result for unregularized feedforward 3 - layer networks under stochastic gradient descent training. They use a neuronal embedding, which comprises of a fixed probability space that encapsulates neural networks of arbitrary sizes. Under suitable regularity and convergence mode assumptions, they prove a universal approximation property, natural of neural networks, which importantly is shown to hold at any finite training time.

This paper proposes a method for learning explanations of expert decisions by modeling their reward function in terms of preferences with respect to “ what if ” outcomes : given the current history of observations, what would happen if we took a particular action? To learn these costbenefit tradeoffs associated with the expert ’s actions, the authors integrate counterfactual reasoning into batch inverse reinforcement learning ( IRL ) to learn the cost - benefit trade - offs associated with expert actions. The authors demonstrate the effectiveness of their approach in recovering accurate and interpretable descriptions of behavior.

This paper proposes a transformer - based approach to solve the problem of MTRL in a graph - based continuous control setting, where the state and action space dimensions are not the same across tasks. The proposed approach is based on the observation that morphological information encoded in the structure of the input graph does not improve the performance of the proposed method. The authors propose a transformer based approach, AMORPHEUS, to address this problem. They conduct ablations on existing methods SMP and NERVENET, and show that the proposed approach outperforms them in terms of sample efficiency and final performance.

This paper proposes a method for visual counting, which aims to predict the number of occurrences given a natural image and a query ( e.g., a question or a category ). Unlike most prior works that use explicit, symbolic models which can be computationally expensive and limited in generalization, the authors propose a simple and effective alternative by revisiting modulated convolutions that fuse the query and the image locally. The authors call their method MoVie, short for Modulated Convex - Volutional Bottlenecks, which only needs a single forward pass during inference. The proposed method is shown to perform well on counting - specific VQA tasks while being more efficient.

This paper presents a method for model - targeted poisoning attacks, where the goal is to induce a model to misclassify a given input. The authors propose an online poisoning attack that can target a desired model based on online convex optimization. They show that the distance from the induced classifier to the target classifier is inversely proportional to the square root of the number of poisoning points. They also provide a lower bound on the minimum number of poisoned points needed to reach the target model.

This paper proposes a new binarization method for real - time point cloud applications that run on edge devices. The authors claim that the performance drop of binarized models for point clouds mainly stems from two challenges : aggregation - induced feature homogenization that leads to a degradation of information entropy, and scale distortion that hinders optimization and invalidates scale - sensitive structures. The proposed method introduces Entropy - Maximizing Aggregation ( EMA ) to modulate the distribution before aggregation for the maximum information entropy and Layer - wise Scale Recovery ( LSR ) to restore feature representation capacity. Extensive experiments show that the proposed method outperforms existing binarizing methods by convincing margins, at the level comparable with the full precision counterpart.

This paper proposes to use memory - augmented neural networks ( MANNs ) to improve the performance of Transformer - based models by adding memory tokens to store non - local representations, creating memory bottleneck for the global information, and controlling memory update with dedicated layer. Experiments show that presence of memory positively correlates with the model performance for machine translation and language modelling tasks.

This paper proposes a method for unsupervised representation learning that combines contrastive learning with clustering. The proposed method uses prototypes as latent variables to help find the maximum - likelihood estimation of the network parameters in an Expectation - Maximization framework. The paper proposes ProtoNCE loss, a generalized version of the InfoNCE for contrastive loss, which encourages representations to be closer to their assigned prototypes. Experiments on multiple benchmarks demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a method to improve the robustness of neural networks against adversarial attacks. The authors propose to embed orthogonal multiple paths into a neural network to enhance robustness. They do so by forcing the follow - up layers to learn to fit all the paths and correcting the features learned by front layers. Experiments are conducted on CIFAR-10 and VGG16 to demonstrate the effectiveness of the method.

This paper proposes a self - supervised graph attention network ( SuperGAT ) for noisy graphs. The proposed method learns to predict edges, whose presence and absence contain the inherent information about the importance of the relationships between nodes in the graph. By encoding edges, the proposed method is able to learn more expressive attention in distinguishing mislinked neighbors. Two graph characteristics influence the effectiveness of attention forms and self - supervision : homophily and average degree.

This paper proposes a new approach to solve the problem of dialogue system for medical automatic diagnosis ( DSMAD ). The proposed approach consists of two modules : an inquiry module for proposing symptom - inquiries and an introspective module for deciding when to inform a disease. The authors propose two evaluation metrics to validate the reliability and robustness of DSMAD methods. They show that the proposed approach achieves the new state - of - the - art under various experimental settings.

This paper proposes a novel and adaptive batch - wise regularization based on the proposed Batch Confusion Norm ( BCN ) to address the natural world distribution which usually involves fine - grained and long - tailed properties at the same time. When inter - class similarity prevails in a batch, the BCN term can alleviate possible overfitting due to exploring image features of fine details. On the other hand, the class predictions from different samples would unavoidably yield a substantial BCN loss, and prompt the network learning to further reduce the cross - entropy loss. The proposed BCN can learn to exert proper distribution of confusion strength over tailed and head categories.

This paper proposes a new method for inverse reinforcement learning ( BIRL ). The proposed method is based on a variational approach to the latent reward. The authors propose to learn an approximate posterior distribution over the reward that scales to arbitrarily complicated state spaces alongside an appropriate policy in a completely offline manner. The method is applied to real medical data and simulated control simulations to demonstrate Bayesian reward inference.

This paper proposes a new method for partially observable POMDPs. The proposed method is based on an approximate auto - regressive counterfactual belief that is learned as a supervised task. The method is applied to two - player Hanabi self - play and is shown to outperform the state - of - the - art methods in terms of computational efficiency.

This paper proposes a new algorithm for tree search that aims to balance the trade - off between depth and breadth of the search. The main idea is to use the multi - step expansion to control the depth of search and inject into planning more randomness via random multiple - step expansions. Experiments show that the proposed method can achieve the best of both worlds consistently achieving higher scores.

This paper proposes a new method for learning inductive bias in the form of synthetic datasets for mathematical reasoning. The authors propose a new pre - training methodology called LIME ( Learning Inductive bias for Mathematical rEasoning ), which is based on the observation that deduction, induction, and abduction form an irreducible set of reasoning primitives. They design three synthetic tasks that are intended to require the model to have these three abilities. They specifically design these synthetic tasks in a way that they are devoid of mathematical knowledge to ensure that only the fundamental reasoning biases can be learned from these tasks. Models trained with LIME significantly outperform vanilla transformers on three large mathematical reasoning benchmarks.

This paper studies the inductive bias of gradient descent for weight normalized smooth homogeneous neural nets, when trained on exponential or cross - entropy loss. The paper focuses on exponential weight normalization ( EWN ), which encourages weight updates along the radial direction. The authors show that the gradient flow path with EWN is equivalent to gradient flow on standard networks with an adaptive learning rate, and hence causes the weights to be updated in a way that prefers asymptotic relative sparsity. The results can be extended to hold for gradient descent via adaptive learning rates.

This paper proposes a method to address the problem of catastrophic forgetting in generative adversarial networks ( GANs ). In particular, the authors observe that the discriminator is unable to maintain classification accuracy on previously seen samples, a phenomenon called catastrophic forgetting. The authors propose a new training procedure that dynamically spawns additional discriminators to remember previous modes of generation. The proposed method is evaluated on several datasets and is shown to mitigate mode collapse and improve standard metrics.

This paper proposes an approach to regularize BERT by pruning its attention heads based on a proxy score for head importance. The paper proposes to use reinforcement learning to automatically prune attention heads from BERT. Instead of relying on heuristics or rule - based policies, the paper proposes a pruning policy that determines which attention heads should or should not be pruned for regularization. Experimental results show that AUBER outperforms existing pruning methods by achieving up to 9.39 % better accuracy.

This paper proposes a method for learning correspondence between two domains, i.e., sim - to - real and real - world, by learning to align the dynamics of the two domains using a cycle - consistency constraint. The proposed method is able to learn the correspondence using unpaired and randomly collected data from two domains. Once the correspondence is found, the proposed method can directly transfer the policy trained on one domain to the other without needing any additional fine - tuning on the second domain.

This paper studies the problem of off - manifold explainability, i.e., the assumption that the model ’s features are uncorrelated. In particular, the authors argue that the Shapley framework for explainability attributes a model’s predictions to its input features in a mathematically principled and model - agnostic way. The authors propose two methods to compute on - manifold Shapley values that respect the data manifold. The first method is based on generative modelling, while the other directly learns Shapley value - function.

This paper proposes a new method for opponent modelling. The proposed method is based on VAE - based variational autoencoders, which are trained to reconstruct the local actions and observations of the opponent based on embeddings conditioned only on the local observations ( observed world state, chosen actions, and received rewards ). The method is evaluated on the multi - agent particle environment and level - based foraging tasks. The results show that the proposed method achieves comparable performance to an ideal baseline which has full access to opponent ’s information.

This paper proposes Consistent Contrast ( CO2 ), a method for unsupervised contrastive learning on unlabeled data. The authors introduce a consistency regularization term to encourage the similarity of the query crop to each crop from other images as “ unlabeled ”, and the corresponding similarity of a positive crop as a pseudo label, and encourage consistency between these two similarities. Empirically, CO2 improves Momentum Contrast ( MoCo ) by 2.9 % on ImageNet linear protocol, 3.8 % and 1.1 % on 1% and 10 % labeled semi - supervised settings, respectively, showing the effectiveness of the method.

This paper studies the last - iterate convergence of Optimistic Gradient Descent Ascent ( OGDA ) and Optimistic Multiplicative Weights Update ( OMWU ) in bilinear games over the probability simplex. The authors show that when the equilibrium is unique, linear last -iterate convergence is achieved with a learning rate whose value is set to a universal constant, improving the result of ( Daskalakis & Panageas, 2019b ) under the same assumption. They further extend the results to more general objectives and feasible sets for the projected OGDA algorithm. Finally, they provide experimental results to further support their theory.

This paper proposes a new method for federated user verification ( UV ) training. The proposed method, FedUV, learns a set of vectors and maximizes the correlation of their instance embeddings with a secret user - defined linear combination of those vectors. The authors show that choosing the linear combinations from the codewords of an error - correcting code allows users to collaboratively train the model without revealing their embedding vectors. Experiments are conducted on voice, face and handwriting recognition datasets.

This paper proposes a new method for estimating the dimension of class manifolds and multi - way class boundary manifolds in the space of inputs for deep neural neural networks. To do so, they use optimization constrained to randomly chosen affine subspaces ( hyperplanes ) of varying dimension. This allows them to extract the effective dimension of the class manifold as well as regions between classes. They show that well - performing, robust models have higher dimensional CMs than worse performing models. Moreover, they offer a unique perspective on ensembling via intersections of CMs.

This paper proposes a novel approach to tackle the trade - off between exploration and exploitation in reinforcement learning ( RL ). In particular, the paper proposes to use the state prediction error to model curiosity because an unfamiliar state generally has a large prediction error. The curiosity is added to the target entropy to increase the entropy temperature for unfamiliar states and decrease the entropy for familiar states. By tuning the entropy specifically and adaptively, CAT - SAC is encouraged to explore when its curiosity is large, otherwise, it is encouraging to exploit.

This paper proposes a meta - reinforcement learning algorithm for out - of - distribution tasks. The proposed method is based on model identification and experience relabeling ( MIER ). The authors propose to use the model identification part of the meta - RL problem as model identification, and then use the experience to relabel the next state and reward on every previously seen transition, obtaining synthetic data to continue training the policy. Experiments show that the proposed method outperforms the baselines on a range of tasks.

This paper proposes a meta - learning method for few - shot learning ( FSL ) where there are only a few available samples with sampling noise and label noise. The paper proposes to treat the meta - overfitting problem as a gradient noise problem, and proposes a gradient - based algorithm Eigen - Reptile to alleviate the gradient noise. Furthermore, the paper proposes Introspective Self - paced Learning ( ISPL ) that constructs a plurality of prior models to determine which sample should be abandoned. The proposed method is evaluated theoretically and experimentally on different tasks.

This paper proposes a method for adversarially perturbing the mean and variance of deep image features to produce models that are robust to distributional shifts. The proposed method, Adversarial Batch Normalization ( AdvBN ), re - normalizes with the most damaging mean and variances of the feature statistics. The method is evaluated on ImageNet - C, Stylized - ImageNet, ImageNet-Instagram, and ImageNetInstagram.

This paper proposes a new metric, Variance of Gradients ( VoG ), to rank data by difficulty and to surface a tractable subset of the most challenging examples for human - in - the - loop auditing. Data points with high VoG scores are far more difficult for the model to learn and over - index on corrupted or memorized examples. The authors provide quantitative and qualitative support that VoG is a meaningful and efficient proxy metric for detecting outliers in the data distribution.

This paper proposes a method to improve samples from deep generative models by refining them using gradient flow of f - divergences between the real and the generator data distributions. The proposed method is based on a non - linear Fokker - Plank equation, which can be easily simulated by sampling from the equivalent McKean - Vlasov process. Experiments on synthetic, image, and text datasets demonstrate that the proposed method can improve the quality of generated samples.

This paper presents a new approach for pre - training Transformer models for cross - lingual understanding and generation tasks. The proposed approach splits the standard Transformer block into several sub - modules trained with both inner - sequence and cross - sequence masked language modeling, and reorganizes certain sub - module for understanding and generating tasks during inference. The approach achieves state - of - the - art results on various language understanding tasks of the XTREME benchmark covering text classification, sequence labeling, question answering, and sentence retrieval.

This paper proposes a novel intrinsic reward for Reinforcement Learning ( RL ) that encourages the agent to understand the causal effect of its actions through auditory event prediction. The authors propose to use a neural network to predict the auditory events and use the prediction errors as intrinsic rewards to guide RL exploration. They conduct an in - depth analysis of their module using a set of Atari games. They apply their model to audio - visual exploration using the Habitat simulator and active learning using the ThreeDWorld ( TDW ) simulator.

This paper presents an end - to - end framework to jointly learn a reliable representation and assign clusters to unlabelled data. To avoid overfitting the learnt embedding to labelled data, the authors propose using category discrimination on labelled data and cross - modal discrimination on multimodal data to augment instance discrimination used in conventional contrastive learning approaches. They further employ Winner - Take - All ( WTA ) hashing algorithm on the shared representation space to generate pairwise pseudo labels for unlabelling data to better predict cluster assignments. They thoroughly evaluate their framework on large - scale video benchmarks Kinetics - 400 and VGG - Sound, and image benchmarks CIFAR10, CIFar100 and ImageNet.

This paper proposes a new weakly supervised segmentation method for image segmentation. The proposed method is based on a semi - supervised metric learning problem, where pixels of the same semantics need to be mapped to the same (distinctive ) features in the feature space. The authors propose 4 types of contrastive relationships between pixels and feature space : low - level image similarity, semantic annotation, co - occurrence, feature affinity, and feature affinity. They show that the proposed method outperforms Pascal VOC and DensePose in terms of performance.

This paper proposes a new self - supervised distillation method named BINGO, which is short for Bag of InstaNces aGgregatiOn. The proposed method aims at transferring the relationship learned by the teacher to the student in relation - guided principle, which shows stronger effectiveness than previous relation - agnostic methods. The method achieves new state - of - the - art performance on small scale models, i.e., 65.5 % and 68.9 % top - 1 accuracies with linear evaluation on ImageNet.

This paper proposes an adversarial approach to simulating - based inference ( SBI ). The authors propose to use adversarial training to learn implicit posterior distributions for SBI. Inference with GATSBI is amortised across observations, works in high - dimensional posterior spaces and supports implicit priors. The proposed method is evaluated on two SBI benchmark problems and on two high -dimensional simulators.

This paper studies the identification and estimation of individualized treatment effects ( TEs ) under limited overlap.   The authors propose a method for CATE estimation with a generative model. The model is learned as a new type of variational autoencoder ( VAE ). The authors derive the TE error bounds that enable representations balanced for treatment groups conditioned on individualized features.

This paper proposes a framework for autonomous reinforcement learning ( ARL ), where the agent learns through its own experience, but also contends with lack of human supervision to reset between trials. The authors introduce a simulated benchmark EARL1 around this framework, containing a set of diverse and challenging simulated tasks reflective of the hurdles introduced to learning when only a minimal reliance on extrinsic intervention can be assumed. They show that standard approaches to episodic RL and existing approaches struggle as interventions are minimized, underscoring the need for developing new algorithms with a greater focus on autonomy.

This paper investigates the problem of over - parameterizing GNN - based QA systems. It shows that the initial node embeddings and some GNN layers are completely dispensable, and that GNN essentially works as a counter in the QA reasoning process. To verify this point, they design soft / hard counter models, which achieve comparable or even better experimental results than existing GNN-based methods.

This paper proposes a new method for Deep Neural Network ( DNN ) inference with near - optimal compression and much better performance during inference runtime. The key insight of the proposed method is the concept of Succinct Data Structures, which supports fast queries directly on compressed representation without decompression. The proposed method first transforms DNN models as their proposed formulations in either Element - wise or Block - wise manner. Then, the method compresses the transformed DNN model using the proposed data structure. Finally, the authors propose a specialized execution pipeline to retrieve relevant data for DNN inference.

This paper proposes a new training method for improving the performance of tiny neural networks. The authors argue that training tiny models is different from training large models : rather than augmenting the data, we should augment the model, since tiny models tend to suffer from under - fitting rather than over - fitting due to limited capacity. To alleviate this issue, NetAug augments the network ( reverse dropout ) instead of inserting noise into the dataset or the network. It puts the tiny model into larger models and encourages it to work as a sub - model of larger models.

This paper proposes a GAN - based method to learn the temporal coherence from point cloud sequence, which in turn guides the generator to produce temporally coherent output. The authors propose a learnable masking module to adapt upsampling ratio according to the point distribution. They conduct experiments on point cloud sequences from two different domains : particles in the fluid dynamical system and human action scanned data. The quantitative and qualitative evaluation demonstrates the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a novel detection transformer named FP - DETR, which fully pre - trains an encoder - only transformer and smoothly finetunes it for object detection via a task adapter. The proposed method leverages query positional embeddings as visual prompts to help the model attend to the target area (prompting ) and recognize the object. Experiments on the challenging COCO dataset demonstrate that the proposed method achieves competitive performance.

This paper proposes a new federated learning algorithm, FedPAGE, to reduce the communication complexity of federated gradient descent ( FedAvg ). The proposed algorithm is based on the recent optimal PAGE method ( Li et al. 2021 ), and it uses much fewer communication rounds than previous local methods for both federated convex and nonconvex optimization. In the convex setting, the number of communication rounds is O(3/4 S ), improving the best - known result O(N 2/3 S ) of SCAFFOLD ( Karimireddy et al, 2020 ) by a factor of N, where N is the total number of clients, S is the sampled subset of clients in each communication round, and is the target error.

This paper studies the decision boundary geometry of neural networks in the presence of adversarial perturbations. The authors define adversarial subspaces, which are spanned by orthogonal directions of minimal perturbation to decision boundary from any given input sample. They show that the decision boundaries lie close to input samples in a large subspace, where the distance to the boundary grows smoothly and sub - linearly as one increases the dimensionality of the subspace. They further show that adversarial training increases the number of alternative label regions in adversarial subsets, and changes the relative distribution of nearby alternate classes.

This paper proposes a contrastive learning approach for weakly - supervised representation learning. The authors argue that a form of the valuable information provided by the auxiliary information is its implied data clustering information. To this end, the authors propose a two - stage approach : ( 1 ) to cluster data according to its auxiliary information ; ( 2 ) to learn similar representations within the same cluster and dissimilar representations for data from different clusters.   The authors conduct experiments on learning visual representations using UT - zappos50K ( Yu & Grauman, 2014 ), CUB - 200 - 2011, Wider Attribute ( Li et al. 2016 ) and ImageNet - 100 datasets.

This paper proposes a method to learn algorithms automatically from data by unrolling a path - following algorithm with some components being more flexible and learnable. Theoretically, the authors show the improved recovery accuracy achievable by PLISA. The authors also analyze the empirical Rademacher complexity of PLISA to characterize its generalization ability to solve new problems outside the training set.

This paper proposes a method to learn a compact and decodable latent representation space for discrete - continuous hybrid action space. The proposed method is based on an embedding table and conditional Variational Auto - Encoder ( VAE ) to embed the dependence between discrete action and continuous parameter via an embeddings table. To further improve the effectiveness, the action representation is trained to be semantically smooth through unsupervised environmental dynamics prediction. Finally, the agent then learns its policy with conventional DRL algorithms in the learned representation space and interacts with the environment by decoding the hybrid action embedding to the original one.

This paper proposes a new method for solving stochastic nonconvex optimization problems based on the AEGD method. The main contribution of the paper is to propose to use both energy and momentum at the same time. The authors show that the proposed method has an unconditional energy stability property, and derive energy - dependent convergence rates in the general non - convex setting, as well as a regret bound in the online convex case. The paper also provides a lower threshold for the energy variable.

This paper proposes a new model for non - autoregressive ( NAR ) machine translation. The proposed model is based on the CMLM architecture. The model is trained on raw data without distillation and achieves state - of - the - art NAR performance on multiple datasets.

This paper proposes a neural network architecture inspired by the WaveNet architecture. The proposed method is based on a spike response model ( SRM ), where the spike response is induced by a population of neurons that are pre - processed to produce spikes in the input signal. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms the state - of - the - art baselines on several datasets for keyword - spotting.

This paper studies the problem of demographic shift, a phenomenon that occurs when the distribution of demographics between training and deployment can change. The authors propose a class of algorithms, called Shifty algorithms, that provide high - confidence behavioral guarantees that hold under demographic shift. They evaluate Shifty using a real - world dataset of university entrance exams and subsequent student success. They show that the learned models avoid bias under demographic shifts, unlike existing methods.

This paper proposes a neural - based approach to solve stochastic dual dynamic programming ( SDDP ) problems. The proposed method is based on a neural model that learns to map problem instances to a piece - wise linear value function within intrinsic low - dimension space, which is architected specifically to interact with a base SDDP solver so that it can accelerate optimization performance on new instances. Experiments show that the proposed method can significantly reduce the problem solving cost without sacrificing solution quality.

This paper proposes a new protocol for private next - token prediction. The proposed method is based on a relaxation of group differentially private prediction ( GPG ). The authors show that the proposed method can be used to prevent privacy violations by language models that were fine - tuned on a private corpus after pre - training on a public corpus. In particular, they show that it can prevent the leakage of information that is unique to any individual user in the private corpus via the relaxation of GPG.

This paper proposes an unsupervised method to detect out - of - distribution ( OOD ) samples using a k - N density estimate with respect to a classification model ’s intermediate activations on indistribution samples. The authors leverage a recent insight about label smoothing, which they call the Label Smoothed Embedding Hypothesis, and show that one of the implications is that the k -NN density estimator performs better as an OOD detection method both theoretically and empirically when the model is trained with label smoothed. Finally, they show that their proposal outperforms many OOD baselines.

This paper proposes a new method for learning representations for non - adversarial generative models. The proposed method is based on a new formulation of the denoising score matching objective, which encodes information needed for denoizing. The authors propose to learn an infinite - dimensional latent code which achieves improvements of state - of - the - art performance on semi - supervised image classification tasks.

This paper proposes a method for goal - conditioned reinforcement learning that learns to reach distant goal - reaching tasks by using planning at training time to automatically generate a curriculum of intermediate states. The authors frame the learning of the goal - conditioned policies as expectation maximization : the E - step corresponds to planning a sequence of waypoints using graph planning, while the M - step aims to learn a goal - conditioning policy to reach those waypoints. Empirically, the authors show that the proposed method is more sample efficient that prior methods.

This paper proposes a new data augmentation method for training neural networks. The proposed method is based on mixup, i.e., perturbing training data in the direction of other randomly - chosen instances in the training set. In particular, the authors propose to perturb the training data by averaging random pairs of sets of k samples from the training dataset. This averaging is done using optimal transport, with displacement interpolation under the Wasserstein metric. The authors demonstrate theoretically and in simulations that the proposed method preserves cluster and manifold structures, and extend theory studying the efficacy of standard mixup to the k - mixup case.

This paper presents a kernelized classification layer for deep neural networks aiming to extract the best possible classifier with embeddings produced by a given representation learner. The proposed method is based on the observation that linear classifiers can be suboptimal for a network with a limited capacity backbone since better nonlinear classifiers could exist in the same embedding vector space. The authors theoretically show that their classification layer optimizes over all possible radial kernel functions on the space of embedding to learn an optimal non - linear classifier. They then demonstrate the usefulness of this layer in learning more model - efficient classifiers in a number of computer vision and NLP tasks.

This paper theoretically analyzes the sources of bias in GNN - based node representation learning. Based on the analysis, several fairness - aware data augmentation frameworks on nodal features and graph structure are developed to reduce the intrinsic bias. Extensive experiments on node classification and link prediction are carried out over real networks in the context of graph contrastive learning.

This paper proposes a new method for estimating treatment effects from observational data in the presence of unmeasured confounders. The authors propose a confounder - balanced IV Regression ( CB - IV ) algorithm to jointly remove the bias from the unmeasurements with IV regression and achieve better bias - variance trade - off in imbalanced treatment distributions due to the observed confoundingers by balancing for treatment effect estimation. The proposed method consists of three main modules : ( 1 ) treatment regression : regressing the treatment with IVs and confoundering like previous nonlinear IV methods for removing the confounding from unme measured confounds ; ( 2 ) confoundER balancing : learning a balanced representation of confounds to eliminate the bias induced by the observed Confounders ; ( 3 ) outcome regression : Regressing the outcome with the predicted treatment and the balanced representation for treatment effects estimation.

This paper studies the problem of model - agnostic meta - learning ( MAML ) in the linear regression setting, where the hardness is related to the rate that gradient descent converges on the task. The authors show that in order to achieve substantial gain over NAL, there must be some discrepancy in hardness among the tasks, and the optimal solutions of the hard tasks must be closely packed with the center far from the center of the easy tasks optimal solutions. They also give numerical and analytical results suggesting that these insights apply to two - layer neural networks.

This paper proposes a new method for sparse source separation ( BSS ) that leverages the data - driven knowledge stemming from realistic simulations or ground - truth data by learning both PALM hyperparameters and variables. The proposed method is based on the unrolling algorithm unfolding / unrolling method proposed by Nasser et al. ( 2021 ). The authors show that the proposed method outperforms other unrolled source separation methods in the semi - blind setting.

This paper proposes a new model architecture for language modeling. The main idea is to use implicit self - attention to improve the performance of transformers. The proposed model is based on a Legendre Memory Unit ( LMU ), which is an extension of the LSTM architecture proposed by Gao et al. ( 2020 ). The authors show that the proposed model can outperform transformers and LSTMs in terms of computational and memory requirements.

This paper proposes a GAN - based approach for disentangling the image into spatial and appearance factors without domain knowledge and supervision signals. The proposed method is trained end - to - end on the classical GAN objective with internal conditioning on a set of space keypoints. These keypoints have associated appearance embeddings that respectively control the position and style of the generated objects and their parts. The authors demonstrate that LatentKeypointGAN provides an interpretable latent space that can be used to re - arrange the generated images by re - positioning and exchanging keypoint embedding.

This paper studies the problem of gradient explosion and representation shrinkage in deep neural networks with layer normalization using mean field formalism. The authors show that increasing the depth leads to gradient explosion or to another undesirable phenomenon we call representation shrunkage. The appearance of at least one of these problems is not restricted to a specific initialization scheme or a choice of activation function, but rather is an inherent property of the fully - connected architecture itself. The paper also shows that many popular normalization techniques fail to mitigate these problems.

This paper proposes a line - search method for finding the optimal step sizes for stochastic gradient descent ( SGD ). The proposed method is based on the observation that the full - batch loss behaves locally parabolically in the direction of noisy update step directions, and the trend of the optimal update step size changes slowly. Based on this observation, the proposed method approximates the full batch loss with a parabola estimated over several mini - batches. The learning rates are derived from such parabolas during training.

This paper studies the problem of noise - contrastive estimation ( NCE ) in the presence of an ill - behaved loss landscape. The authors propose a new loss function called eNCE, which replaces the log loss in NCE with an exponential loss, and they show that the resulting condition number is polynomial in the dimension and the parameter distance between P and Q when they belong to an exponential family. The proposed loss function can be efficiently optimized using normalized gradient descent and empirically outperforms existing methods.

This paper studies the problem of how to combine differential privacy ( DP ) and Byzantine resilience ( BR ) in distributed machine learning. The authors show that the integration of standard practices in DP and BR is not straightforward. They show that many existing results on the convergence of distributed SGD under Byzantine faults, especially those relying on ( α, f)-Byzantine resilience, are rendered invalid when honest workers enforce DP. To circumvent this shortcoming, they revisit the theory of ( α, f)-BR to obtain an approximate convergence guarantee.

This paper considers the problem of code editing with few exemplars. The paper proposes a novel deep learning approach to solve this code editing problem automatically. The proposed method combines edit representations extracted from support exemplars and compositionally generalizes them to the query code snippet editing via multi - entent similarities ensemble. The authors evaluate the proposed method on C# and Python datasets and show up to 8.6 % absolute accuracy improvements compared to non - composition baselines.

This paper proposes a novel approach for incorporating high - level structure to guide the generative process in the form of relational constraints between different subcomponents of an example ( e.g., lines of a poem or measures of music ). The authors propose a program synthesis algorithm that infers the relational constraints present in the training data, and then learns a generative model based on the resulting constraint data. The experiments show that the proposed approach significantly improves over state - of - the - art in terms of capturing high level structure in the data, while performing comparably or better in low - level structures.

This paper proposes a new method for set - to - hypergraph prediction. The main contribution of the paper is to propose to predict and supervise the set of positive edges only, which changes the asymptotic memory scaling from exponential to linear. The paper also proposes a training method that encourages iterative refinement of the predicted hypergraph, which allows us to skip iterations in the backward pass for improved efficiency and constant memory usage. Experiments show that the proposed method outperforms prior state - of - the - art models.

This paper proposes a post - processing method to mitigate bias of state - of - the - art models. It consists in learning a shallow neural network, called the Ethical Module, which transforms the deep embeddings of a pre - trained model to give more representation power to the discriminated subgroups. Its training is supervised by the von Mises - Fisher loss, whose hyperparameters allow to control the space allocated to each subgroup in the latent space. Besides being very simple, the resulting methodology is more stable and faster than most current methods of bias mitigation.

This paper proposes a new method for class - incremental learning ( CIL ). The proposed method is based on the use of placebos to improve the KD loss between the models learned in adjacent phases, while not harming the learning of new classes in the new model. The authors propose a reinforcement learning - based algorithm that learns a policy to produce phase - specific functions to evaluate the quality of the placebos and collect good ones. Experiments show that the proposed method can outperform existing methods on CIFAR-100 and ImageNet-1k datasets.

This paper proposes a new approach for sampling from discrete distributions in energy - based models ( EBMs ). In particular, the authors propose a path auxiliary algorithm that uses a composition of local moves to efficiently explore large neighborhoods. The authors also give a fast version of their algorithm that only queries the evaluation of energy function twice for each proposal via linearization of the energy function. Empirically, they show that their method can outperform other generic samplers on various discrete models for sampling, inference, and learning.

This paper presents a method for learning a hierarchical generative model that can predict the onset of events in a spatiotemporal hierarchy based on the rate of change in the spatio - temporal factors of variation of the data. The method is based on a neural probabilistic inference system that is trained to predict the arrival of the expected and the unexpected events. The model is able to detect the event boundaries, disentangle spatio-temporal features across its hierarchy, adapt to the dynamics of the dataset, and produce accurate time - agnostic rollouts of the future.

This paper proposes a single - stage image retrieval method that combines spatial and channel attention to learn key local information, then feeds it to CNN to learn homography transformation in images. Through information fusion, UGALR produces multi - attentive features that contain both global and local information. Experiments on Revisited Oxford and Paris datasets validate the effectiveness.

This paper proposes RotoGrad, an algorithm that homogenizes gradient magnitudes and directions across tasks in multi - task learning ( MTL ) to avoid negative transfer. In particular, the gradient magnitude is homogenized in terms of magnitude and directions, and the direction - homogenization is homogeneous. The proposed method is evaluated on the CIFAR10 and NYUv2 datasets, and it is shown to outperform competing methods in the multi - label classification setting.

This paper proposes a model fusion method for fusing heterogeneous neural networks. The proposed method is based on cross - layer alignment, which is an assignment problem using layer representation and layer similarity, followed by a layer balancing step to balance the number of layers between two networks. Experiments are conducted on CIFAR-10 and ResNet datasets to show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the effect of the implicit regularization effect of stochastic gradient descent ( SGD ) in the offline deep RL setting. The authors derive the form of this implicit regularizer and propose a simple and effective explicit regularizer, called DR3, that counteracts the undesirable effects of this regularizer. Empirically, using DR3 in conjunction with existing offline RL methods provides about 60 % performance improvement on the harder D4RL tasks, and 160 % and 25 % stability gains for REM and CQL respectively, on offline RL tasks in 17 Atari 2600 games.

This paper proposes a new method for randomized exploration in deep RL. The proposed method is based on a probabilistic hypermodel, which can generate approximate posterior samples regarding the parameter of the Q - value function. The authors evaluate the proposed method on the Atari suite and show that it outperforms the baselines in terms of the human - normalized score over 49 tasks.

This paper proposes to learn causal representation from observational data by regularizing the learning procedure with mutual information measures according to a hypothetical causal graph. The authors derive a theoretical guarantee that the causality - inspired learning is with reduced sample complexity and better generalization ability. Extensive experiments show that the models trained on causal representations learned by the proposed method is robust under adversarial attacks and distribution shift.

This paper proposes ProgFed, a progressive training framework for efficient and effective federated learning. It inherently reduces computation and two - way communication costs while maintaining the strong performance of the final models. Theoretically, the proposed method converges at the same asymptotic rate as standard training on full models. Extensive experiments on various datasets ( CIFAR-10/100, EMNIST and BraTS ) and architectures ( VGG-16/19, ResNet-18/152, ConvNets, 3D - Unet ) show that with the same number of epochs, it can save around 25 % computation cost, up to 32 % two - sided communication costs in federated classification, and up to 63 % communication costs for federated segmentation.

This paper studies the generalization of adversarial training through the lens of the adversarial Rademacher complexity of deep neural networks. The authors provide an upper bound on the adversarially trained weight norms and show that they are larger than the standard trained weight norm. They also provide experiments to show that the large weight norms are a key factor explaining the bad generalization performance of adversariar training.

This paper proposes a kernel - based estimator for differential entropy and mutual information estimation. The proposed estimator is based on a differentiable kernel, and can be used for both conditional ( on discrete or continuous variables ) and continuous ( on continuous or discrete variables ) differential entropy, as well as mutual information. Experiments are conducted on image domain adaptation, fair classification, and textual fine - tuning tasks.

This paper proposes a new soft - greedy operator, called resmax, that takes actions proportionally to their suboptimality gap : the residual to the estimated maximal value. It is simple to use and ensures coverage of the state - space, but focuses exploration more on potentially promising actions like softmax. It does not concentrate probability as quickly as softmax, and so better avoids overemphasizing sub - optimal actions that appear high - valued during learning. The authors prove that it is a non - expansion for any fixed exploration hyperparameter, unlike the softmax policy which requires a state - action specific temperature to obtain a nonexpansion ( called mellowmax ).

This paper introduces a new concept called “ learnability lock ” for controlling the model ’s learnability on a specific dataset with a special key. In particular, they propose adversarial invertible transformation, that can be viewed as a mapping from image to image, to slightly modify data samples so that they become “ unlearnable ” by machine learning models with negligible loss of visual features. Meanwhile, one can unlock the learnability of the dataset and train models normally using the corresponding key.
