The proposed learnability key leverages class - wise perturbation that applies a universal transformation function on data samples of the same label. This ensures that the learnable can be easily restored with a simple inverse transformation while remaining difficult to be detected or reverse - engineered.

This paper proposes a novel method for handling missing features in graph machine learning applications. The proposed method is based on minimization of the Dirichlet energy and leads to a diffusion - type differential equation on the graph. The discretization of this equation produces a simple, fast and scalable algorithm which is called Feature Propagation ( FP ). Experiments show that the proposed approach outperforms previous methods on seven common node - classification benchmarks and can withstand surprisingly high rates of missing features.

This paper studies the problem of active learning, i.e., the process of training a model with limited labeled data by selecting a core subset of an unlabeled data pool to label. The paper introduces an integer optimization problem for selecting the core set that minimizes the discrete Wasserstein distance from the unlabelled pool.   The paper shows that this problem can be solved with a Generalized Benders Decomposition algorithm. Numerical results on several data sets show that the proposed method is competitive with baselines and outperforms them in the low budget regime.

This paper proposes a method for de - novo genome assembly by finding a path through the assembly graph. The method is based on a graph convolutional neural network, which is trained on a dataset generated from human genomic data to reconstruct the genome by finding the shortest path in the graph topology. The authors show that their model can compute scores from the lengths of the overlaps between the sequences and the topology which, when traversed with a greedy search algorithm, outperforms the greedy search over the overlap lengths only. Moreover, their method reconstructs the correct path in a fraction of the time required for the state - of - the - art de novo assemblers.

This paper proposes to use experience replay ( ER ) in meta - learning to improve continual learning representations by integrating ER also into meta - training. The authors propose to store the samples ’ representations, instead of the samples themselves, into the replay buffer. This ensures the batch nature of ER does not conflict with the online - aware nature of meta - continual learning. Moreover, the authors introduce a meta - learned Predictive Sample Selection to replace the widely used reservoir sampling to populate the replay buffers.

This paper proposes a new method for multi - agent joint Q - learning based on centralized training with decentralized execution ( CTE ). The proposed method is based on an explicit credit assignment problem where each agent gives its suggestion about how to weight individual Q - values to explicitly maximize the joint Q-value, besides guaranteeing the Bellman optimality of the Q - value. Theoretically, the authors give a gradient ascent solution for this problem. Empirically, it is shown that the proposed method achieves interpretable credit assignment and superior performance compared to several advanced baselines.

This paper studies the problem of attacking transductive learning - based adversarial defense mechanisms. The authors propose a new framework, Greedy Model Space Attack ( GMSA ), to attack the model space for solving bilevel attack objectives. They show that GMSA, even with weak instantiations, can break some of the existing defenses. They also show that adversarially retraining the model using fresh randomness at the test time gives a significant increase in robustness against attacks.

This paper proposes a new method for batch normalization. The authors consider the case where the entire dataset is normalized jointly, and explore other ways to approximate the gradient from this limiting case. They demonstrate an approximation that removes the need to keep more than one example in memory at any given time, at the cost of a small factor increase in the training step computation, as well as a fully per - example training procedure. They further use their insights to improve batch renormalization for very small minibatches.

This paper proposes a low - rank adaptation ( LoRA ) method to reduce the number of trainable parameters for downstream tasks. Compared to Adam, the proposed method can reduce the total number of parameters by 10,000 times and the memory requirement by 3 times. The proposed method is evaluated on a number of downstream tasks, and is shown to perform on - par or better than Adam.

This paper proposes a method to constrain the output of linear - chain conditional random fields ( CRF ) to a regular language. The authors propose a regular - constrained CRF ( RegCCRF ) that can enforce a broad class of constraints, including non - local ones, by specifying the space of possible output structures as a regular Language L. The resulting regular - restricted CRF has the same formal properties as a standard CRF, but assigns zero probability to all label sequences not in L.   The authors prove that constrained training is never worse than constrained decoding.

This paper presents a method for camera - based physiological measurement. The authors propose two novel and efficient neural models that remove the need for face detection, segmentation, normalization, color space transformation or any other preprocessing steps. The proposed methods achieve state - of - the - art accuracy on three public datasets. The latency of the proposed networks is evaluated.

This paper proposes a new method for hardware - aware pruning of neural networks. The proposed method is based on a global resource allocation optimization problem, aiming at maximizing the accuracy while constraining the latency under a predefined budget. The method is evaluated on both classification and detection tasks, over varying networks, on ImageNet and VOC datasets.

This paper proposes a new method for molecular graph generation based on energy - based models ( EBMs ). The proposed method is based on contrastive divergence and Langevin dynamics. The authors propose a simple yet effective learning strategy, which pushes down energies with flexible degrees according to the properties of corresponding molecules. Further, the authors explore to use the method for generating molecules towards multiple objectives via compositional generation, which is practically desired in drug discovery.

This paper proposes a new method for program synthesis, CROSSBEAM, which uses a neural model to learn a hands - on search policy for bottom - up synthesis, instead of relying on a combinatorial search algorithm. The model is trained on - policy using data extracted from its own bottom - ups searches on training tasks. The proposed method is evaluated in two domains, string manipulation and inductive logic programming, and it is shown to outperform BUSTLE in both domains.

This paper proposes a new objective to replace the standard squared Bellman error in deep reinforcement learning. The new objective is based on a functional regularization of the target Q - values. The authors propose to use up - to - date parameters as well as control the regularization. This leads to a faster yet more stable training method. Empirical results show that the proposed objective can be used to improve the sample efficiency and performance of DQN.

This paper proposes a new approach to designing graph neural networks ( GNNs ) based on the notion of local isomorphism, i.e., the ability to inject structural properties of graphs into a message - passing aggregation scheme. Theoretically, the authors show that the proposed approach is more expressive than the Weisfeiler Lehman test ( 1 - WL ) in distinguishing graph structures. Empirically, they show that their approach outperforms the state - of - the - art methods on node classification and graph classification benchmark tasks.

This paper proposes a novel prediction interval ( PI ) method for uncertainty quantification. The proposed method is based on linear combinations of three NNs, each of which is independently trained using the standard mean squared error loss. The coefficients of the linear combinations are computed using root - finding algorithms to ensure tight PIs for a given confidence level. The authors theoretically prove that PI3NN can calculate PIs without retraining NNs and it completely avoids the crossing issue.

This paper proposes a method for online meta - learning that does not require any ground truth knowledge about the task boundaries and stays fully online without resetting back to pretrained weights. The proposed method is evaluated on Rainbow - MNIST and CIFAR100 datasets and shows that it can learn to adapt to new tasks faster than the state - of - the - art online learning methods.

This paper proposes a method to make the molecular optimization problem differentiable at the substructure level. The authors propose a differentiable scaffolding tree ( DST ) to convert discrete chemical structures to locally differentiable ones by backpropagating the derivatives from the target properties through a graph neural network ( GNN ). They demonstrate encouraging preliminary results on de novo molecular optimization with multiple computational objective functions.

This paper proposes a personalized lab test result prediction approach that learns a strong patient representation incorporating both patient information accumulated over the visits as well as information from other similar patients. The authors augment the patient representation with the knowledge of drug - lab interactions, diagnosis - lab interaction, and use graph attention networks to model the positive and negative effects of drugs and diagnosis on the target lab result. Experiments on real - world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed solution in reducing prediction errors by a significant margin.

This paper proposes a new domain generalization problem, called Open - Set Single Domain Generalization ( OS - SDG ), where the target domains may include unseen categories out of the source label space. The authors propose a novel approach named CrossMatch to address the OS -SDG problem, which generates auxiliary samples for unknown classes and improves the capability of unknown classes identification with a novel consistency regularization. Experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of CrossMatch on enhancing the performance of existing single domain generalisation methods.

This paper proposes two extensions of trust - region methods based on Kullback - Leibler divergence ( TRPO ) and Sinkhorn trust regions ( PPO ) for policy optimization. The main idea is to directly optimize the policy distribution and derive their close - form policy updates based on the Lagrangian duality. Theoretically, they show that WPO guarantees a monotonic performance improvement, and SPO provably converges to WPO as the entropic regularizer diminishes. Experiments on tabular domains and robotic locomotion tasks demonstrate the performance improvement of both approaches.

This paper proposes a forget - and - re - learn framework to unify many existing iterative training algorithms in the image classification and language emergence literature to understand the success of these algorithms in terms of the disproportionate forgetting of undesirable information. The authors show that many existing algorithms which have successfully demonstrated improved generalization have a forgetting step that disproportionately affects undesirable information for the given task. They show that the relearning stage amplifies the unforgotten information, and distills from it features that are consistently useful under different initial conditions induced by the forgetting step.

This paper studies the offline - online batch RL setting, where the agent has access to a batch of data to train on but is also allowed to learn during the evaluation phase in an online manner. This is an extension to batch RL, allowing the agent to adapt to new situations without having to precommit to a policy. The authors show that standard RL agents trained in an offline - offline manner can outperform agents trained only offline or online.

This paper studies the problem of domain generalization ( DG ) via meta - learning to reduce domain shift with an episodic training procedure. In particular, it measures the domain shift using Y - discrepancy and learn to optimize Y - discrepancy between the unseen target domain and source domains only using source - domain samples. Theoretically, it gives a PAC - style generalization bound for discrepancy - optimal meta learning and further makes comparisons with other DG bounds including ERM and domain - invariant learning. Empirically, the proposed method achieves state - of - the - art results on two DG benchmarks.

This paper studies the problem of best - first search in the Sokoban domain, where the search space is exponential in terms of the number of sub - trees in the tree. The authors propose to use the policy ( action selection ) and value ( remaining distance estimate ) functions as well as randomization methods for solving hard planning instances using best first search. They show the existence of left heavy tails and propose an abstract tree model that can empirically explain the appearance of these tails.

This paper proposes a meta - imitation learning method for video demonstrations. The proposed method is based on a generative model A - CycleGAN, which is able to translate human videos into practical robot demonstrations and train the meta - policy with adaptive loss based on the quality of the translated data. The method achieves comparable performance to the baseline on fast learning a set of vision - based tasks through watching a single video demonstration.

This paper proposes a new method to improve the performance of over - parameterized deep networks trained using gradient - based optimizers. The proposed method is based on weight - norm - constrained training, where the training loss is constrained by the weight norm of the network. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms the baselines on a variety of tasks, optimizers, and batch sizes.

This paper proposes a method for learning partial and full group equivariance in G - CNNs. In particular, the authors propose a family of networks that can learn both partial ( partial ) and full ( full ) equivariant representations of the data. The proposed method is evaluated on MNIST, 6 / 9 and natural image classification tasks.

This paper proposes a new method for amortized Langevin dynamics ( ALD ) for deep latent variable models. The proposed method replaces the datapoint - wise MCMC iterations with updates of an inference model that maps observations into latent variables. The authors prove that ALD has the target posterior as a stationary distribution under some assumptions. They also show that the proposed method can be extended to sampling from an unconditional distribution.

This paper proposes a method for hypergraph reasoning based on sparsity and locality. The method is based on the observation that in logical reasoning, logical rules usually apply locally ( e.g., only three people are involved in a grandparent rule ) and sparsely ( i.e., the grandparent relationship is sparse across all pairs of people in the world ). To leverage the sparsity in hypergraph neural networks, the proposed method represents the grounding of relationships such as parent and grandparent as sparse tensors and uses neural networks and finite - domain quantification operations to infer new facts. To remedy the information loss in sampled subgraphs, the authors propose a sampling and label calibration paradigm based on an information - theoretic measure information sufficiency.

This paper proposes a new family of differentiable top - k cross - entropy classification losses, which relax the assumption of a fixed k. The authors show that relaxing k does not only produce better top - 5 accuracy, but also makes models more robust, which leads to top - 1 accuracy improvements.   The authors also propose splitter selection nets, which require fewer layers than existing selection nets and achieve new state - of - the - art results on ImageNet1K.

This paper proposes a method for solving large - scale optimal transport ( OT ) problems at an unprecedented combination of speed and accuracy. The proposed method builds on the celebrated Douglas - Rachford splitting technique and tackles the original OT problem directly instead of solving an approximate regularized problem, as many state - of - the - art techniques do. This allows the authors to provide sparse transport plans and avoid numerical issues of methods that use entropic regularization. The algorithm has the same cost per iteration as the popular Sinkhorn method, and each iteration can be executed efficiently.

This paper proposes a framework for disentangling performance gaps in federated learning from out - of - sample ( OOD ) and participation gaps ( participation gap ) in order to better understand generalization in FL. The authors propose a dataset synthesis strategy that enables realistic simulation without naturally - partitioned data. They conduct a systematic study of generalization performance in FL across six tasks. They observe and explain differences in behavior across natural and synthetic federated datasets.

This paper studies the few - shot learning methods on pretrained language models from the BERT family in the zero - shot setting. The authors show that simply introducing a few prompt [ MASK ]s could significantly improve the performance and robustness of the null - prompt method and even exceed cherry - piked manual prompts. They also show that a coarse - to - fine study to learn the influence of multiple components in their proposed method.

This paper proposes a method to improve the alignment and interpretability of attention in image recognition. The proposed method is based on a sharpener module that aims to align relevant parts of the encoded image with the target output. Experiments on synthetic handwritten digits and real - world text recognition datasets show that the proposed method outperforms other methods in terms of accuracy and alignment.

This paper proposes a supervised approach to solve the vehicle routing problem. The proposed approach is based on a reinforcement learning framework that constructs a complete tour plan from scratch while respecting an apriori fixed number of available vehicles. The authors show that the proposed method is faster and easier to train and achieves competitive results that incorporate the practical aspect of vehicle costs.

This paper proposes a method to improve link prediction by counterfactual inference. The proposed method uses causal models to learn the causal relationship between global graph structure and link existence. The method is evaluated on several benchmark datasets and outperforms competitive baseline methods on link prediction tasks.

This paper proposes a two - stage unsupervised feature selection method for feature selection via knowledge contrastive disTillation ( SOFT ) model that incorporates the second - order covariance matrix with the first - order data matrix. In the first stage, the proposed method learns a sparse attention matrix that can represent second order relations between features. The second stage builds a graph based on the learned attention matrix and performs graph segmentation to select high - correlated features together. Experiments on 12 public datasets show that SOFT outperforms classical and recent state - of - the - art methods.

This paper proposes a new method for learning multimodal VAEs that combine information between modalities implicitly through mutual supervision. The proposed method is based on the notion of ‘ relatedness ’, a notion of semantic similarity between data modalities in the latent representation. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms baselines on the MNIST - SVHN ( image - image ) and CUB ( text - text ) datasets.

This paper proposes a method to combine intrinsic and extrinsic rewards in the Dopamine framework for deep reinforcement learning. The proposed method is based on J - PER, a new transitionselection algorithm based on the interest of multiple agents. The authors show that the proposed method achieves 50 % faster wall - clock speed and building a stronger representation. They also show that they can learn from multiple intrinsic rewards and ignore harmful intrinsic rewards.

This paper proposes a new method for learning stiffness - aware neural networks for learning Hamiltonian dynamical systems from data. The proposed method is based on a stiffness - aware index, a simple yet effective metric to quantify the stiffness of the dynamical system. This classification along with a resampling technique allows to apply different time integration strategies such as step size adaptation to better capture the dynamic characteristics of the Hamiltonian vector fields. The method is evaluated on a three - body problem and a billiard model.

This paper presents a method to train language models to perform complex multi - step computations. The authors train Transformers to emit intermediate computation steps into a “ scratchpad ”, which they call “ long addition ” or “ execution of arbitrary programs ”. They show that this method can improve the performance of language models on a series of tasks, including long addition, execution of programs, and program generation.

This paper proposes a novel method to generate adversarial perturbations that are interpretable, universal to any source image, and physically - realizable. The method is based on image generators and a novel optimization objective. The authors show that they can generate targeted feature - level adversarial attacks at the ImageNet scale that are simultaneously interpretable and universal. They also show that the proposed method can also reveal spurious, semantically -describable feature / class associations that can be exploited by novel combinations of natural objects.

This paper presents a novel approach to simulated annealing based on reinforcement learning. In particular, the authors propose to treat the proposal distribution as a policy, which can be optimised for higher solution quality given a fixed computational budget. The proposed approach outperforms baselines with hand - selected parameters on a number of problems.

This paper studies the problem of non - stationarity in cooperative multi - agent reinforcement learning ( MARL ). In this paper, the authors introduce a novel notion, the δ-stationarity measurement, to explicitly measure the non -stationarity of a policy sequence, which can be further proved to be bounded by the KL - divergence of consecutive joint policies. The authors propose a trust - region decomposition network ( TRD - Net ) based on message passing to estimate the joint policy divergence more accurately. Experiments show that MAMT can bring noticeable and stable performance improvement and more suitable for large - scale scenarios.

This paper proposes a method for audio - visual speech representation learning based on multi - stream video input. The authors propose a self - supervised representation learning framework, AV - HuBERT, to learn multimodal hidden units for audio and visual speech. The proposed method is evaluated on the LRS3 lip - reading dataset, where it outperforms the state - of - the - art approach ( Makino et al. 2019 ) trained with a thousand times more transcribed video data ( 31 K hours ).

This paper proposes a novel algorithm for combinatorial optimisation on graphs. The proposed method is based on a recurrent unit - based RL algorithm. The main idea is to restrict the GNN to a single pre - processing step, before entering a fast - acting exploratory phase directed by the recurrent unit. Experiments show that the proposed method achieves a new SOTA for RL algorithms on the Maximum Cut problem, while also providing orders of magnitude improvement in speed and scalability.

This paper proposes a new approach to train VAEs with discrete latent variables. The authors propose to use a direct discrete optimization for the encoding model. They do so by using truncated posteriors in conjunction with evolutionary algorithms ( using a recently suggested approach ). The proposed approach is shown to be more efficient than amortization and sampling - based VAE training.

This paper proposes an unsupervised method based on counterfactual measures of blame to identify effects on the environment controlled by the agent. The proposed method is evaluated in a wide range of environments showing that it can accurately identify controlled effects. It is also evaluated as an intrinsic motivator by integrating it in the state - of - the - art exploration method, achieving substantially better performance than action - prediction models.

This paper proposes a new method for lightweight image super - resolution ( SR ) networks. The proposed method is based on structure - regularized pruning ( SRP ), which imposes regularization on the pruned structure to make sure the locations of pruned filters are aligned across different layers. For the layers connected by the same residual, the authors select the filters of the same indices as unimportant filters. The authors apply SRP to train efficient image SR networks, resulting in a lightweight network SRPN - L and a very deep one SRPN.

This paper proposes a framework for few - shot learning that tackles large domain shift between base and novel categories. The first step of the framework trains a feature extracting backbone with the contrastive loss on the base category data. The second step trains a masking module to select relevant features that are more suited to target domain classification. Finally, a classifier is fine - tuned along with the backbone such that the backbone produces features similar to the relevant ones.

This paper studies the generalization ability of neural networks trained by Bayesian inference and gradient descent. In particular, the authors show that the average test error of the neural network - Gaussian process ( NNGP ) posterior is worse than the average of the test error for Gaussian processes with large margin. The authors also show that gradient descent can be used to select large margin functions with vanishing posterior probability that nonetheless generalize significantly better than the posterior average.

This paper proposes a new method to improve the cross - lingual transfer performance. The proposed method is based on the idea of cross - language manifold mixup ( X - Mixup ), which adaptively calibrates the representation discrepancy and gives compromised representations for target languages. Experiments on the XTREME benchmark show X -Mixup achieves 1.8 % performance gains on multiple text understanding tasks, compared with strong baselines, and reduces the cross language representation discrepancy significantly.

This paper studies the problem of Byzantine robust distributed or federated learning, where a fraction of the workers may deviate from the prescribed algorithm and send arbitrary messages to the server. The authors propose a simple bucketing scheme that adapts existing robust algorithms to heterogeneous datasets at a negligible computational cost. They also theoretically and experimentally validate their approach, showing that combining bucketing with existing robust methods is effective against challenging attacks.

This paper studies the relationship between disentanglement and multi - task learning based on hard parameter sharing. The authors use a set of standard metrics to show that disentangling appears naturally during the process of multi - tasks neural network training. They verify their hypotheses by training multiple models in single - and multiple - task settings and investigating the level of disentangledness achieved in their latent representations. In their experiments, they find that in a hard - parameter sharing scenario multi -task learning indeed seems to encourage disenanglement.

This paper presents a framework of certifying robust policies for reinforcement learning against adversarial state perturbations.   The authors propose two types of robustness certification criteria : robustness of per - state actions and lower bound of cumulative rewards. Specifically, the authors propose a local smoothing algorithm that uses a policy derived from Q - functions smoothed with Gaussian noise over each encountered state to guarantee the robustness to adversarial perturbation. The authors also propose a global smoothing method for certifying cumulative reward robustness under adversarial attacks.

This paper proposes a new approach to conformal prediction, which aims to output a precise set of promising prediction candidates that is guaranteed to contain a limited number of incorrect answers. The authors propose to trade coverage for precision by enforcing that the presence of incorrect candidates in the predicted conformal sets ( i.e., the total number of false positives ) is bounded according to a user - specified tolerance. Subject to this constraint, the proposed method optimizes for a generalized notion of set coverage (   the true positive rate ) that allows for any number of true answers for a given query ( including zero ).

This paper studies the problem of measuring the complexity of a neural network. The authors show that the expected length distortion does not grow with depth, and indeed shrinks slightly, for ReLU networks with standard random initialization. They also generalize this result by proving upper bounds both for higher moments of the length distortion and for the distortion of higher - dimensional volumes. These theoretical results are corroborated by experiments.

This paper proposes a new method for learning safe and unsafe policies in the context of reinforcement learning. The proposed method is based on contrastive training on both the safe and the unsafe data, where the safety variable is inferred from offline data and the safety skills are learned from the data. In the inference stage, the proposed method composes a safe and successful policy according to the inferred safety variable and abstract action in different scenarios. Experiments are conducted on a set of complex robotic grasping tasks to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

This paper proposes a multi - branch model for image restoration. The proposed model is based on the RGC ( Retinal Ganglion Cells ). The model is trained on three image restoration tasks : image dehazing, deraindrop, deblurring, and streak rain removal. Experiments are conducted on synthetic and real - world datasets to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed model.

This paper proposes a new federated learning setup, Inference - time PFL ( IT - PFL ), where a model trained on a set of clients needs to be later evaluated on novel unlabeled clients at inference time. The proposed approach is based on a hypernetwork module and an encoder module. It is evaluated on four benchmark datasets, showing that it generalizes better than current FL and PFL methods, especially when the novel client has a large domain shift.

This paper presents a method to visualize representations learned with self - supervised learning models. The method is based on a conditional diffusion - based generative model ( RCDM ), which is used to evaluate the quality of the generated images. The authors show that the proposed method is more robust to small adversarial perturbations of the inputs, and that there is an inherent structure learned with SSL model that can be used for image manipulation.

This paper studies the Fp sketch, a well - known algorithm for frequency moments estimation, which is differentially private as is when p = ( 0, 1 ). The authors show that its pure multiplicative sensitivity is approximately max{22p+2, 22p-2 } when p \in ( 0, 1 ) and n M. They show that the algorithm is exponentially better than existing DP baselines and only worse than the optimal non - private baseline by a logarithmic factor.

This paper proposes a reward - switching policy optimization ( RSPO ) method for discovering diverse strategies in complex RL environments by iteratively finding novel policies that are both locally optimal and sufficiently different from existing ones. To encourage the learning policy to consistently converge towards a previously undiscovered local optimum, the proposed method switches between extrinsic and intrinsic rewards via a trajectory - based novelty measurement during the optimization process. The proposed method is able to discover a wide spectrum of strategies in a variety of domains, ranging from single - agent particle - world tasks and MuJoCo continuous control to multi - agent stag - hunt games and StarCraftII challenges.

This paper proposes a method for finding fast diffusion model samplers by optimizing the degrees of freedom of Generalized Gaussian Diffusion Models ( GGDM ) by maximizing sample quality scores via gradient descent. The authors propose to use the reparametrization trick and gradient rematerialization to optimize over a parametric family of parametric non - Markovian Samplers for diffusion models. The proposed method achieves good results on unconditional image generation with only 10 inference steps and 4.82 with 20 steps.

This paper proposes a method for extracting factual information from large language models ( LLMs ). The authors argue that the quality of the factual information extracted from LLMs depends on the prompts used to query them. To address this shortcoming, the authors propose P - adapters : lightweight models that sit between the embedding layer and first attention layer of LLMs. They take LLM embeddings as input and output continuous prompts that are used to queries the LLM. They show that the proposed method outperforms other methods in terms of accuracy and consistency.

This paper proposes a method for continuous classification of time series ( CCTS ), which is a continual learning task with the unclear distribution division. The authors propose a novel Adaptive model training policy ( ACCTS ) to overcome two main problems : catastrophic forgetting and overfitting. Experiments on four real - world datasets show that the proposed method can classify more accurately than all baselines at every time.

This paper proposes to use external memory for language modeling. The authors propose a simple extension to the transformer architecture, called kNN - augmented attention, which dramatically increases the length of the context that a language model can attend to by using k - nearest - neighbor lookup into a large external memory. They show that the performance steadily improves when we increase the size of memory up to 131k tokens. They also show that models can generalize to larger memory sizes than they were trained on.

This paper proposes a sampling scheme based on the Metropolis - hastings Monte Carlo algorithm to generate sequences from MLMs. The proposed method is based on two energy parametrizations derived from the trained MLMs and the proposed sampling scheme. The authors show that the proposed method can generate high - quality samples from non - probabilistic masked language models.

This paper proposes a new method for data augmentation for NLP tasks. The authors propose a new reward function for learning the best augmentation strategy for each NLP task. The proposed method is based on the idea that good augmentation should construct more diverse and challenging samples for providing informative training signals, while avoiding the risk of losing the semantics of original samples. To this end, the authors propose to jointly optimize the augmentation policy while training the model, to construct the augmented samples with low confidence but a high semantic similarity with original ones. In addition, they introduce a sample re - weighting scheme to focus on difficult augmented samples after the original ones are learned confidently.

This paper proposes a new method for offline reinforcement learning ( ORL ) based on meta - learning. The proposed method is based on a combination of intra - task attention mechanism and inter - task contrastive learning objectives to achieve robust task inference. Theoretical analysis and experiments are presented to demonstrate the superior performance and robustness of the proposed method compared to model - free methods.

This paper proposes a method for improving the accuracy of a partially observable Markov system given sample - access to its dynamics model. The authors propose an inference - time improvement framework for parametric sequential generative modeling methods called belief fine - tuning ( BFT ). BFT leverages approximate dynamic programming to determine the model parameters at each time step. It can improve the accuracy at test time because it specializes the capacity of the model to the space of local observations and does not require the belief model to process it as input.

This paper proposes a new method for sparsity - based training of neural networks. The authors propose to optimize over a continuous superset of sparse matrices with a fixed structure known as products of butterfly matrices. The proposed method uses a simple fixed sparsity pattern based on flat block butterfly and low - rank matrices to sparsity most network layers ( e.g., attention, MLP ). The paper empirically shows that the proposed method can speed up the training of models ( Transformers, ViT, MLPMixer ) without quality drop compared to baselines on a wide range of domains and tasks.

This paper proposes a novel conditional diffusion probabilistic model ( ST - DDPM ) to model the class center in the forward process of the Markov chain and explore the class clustering phenomenon. The learned class centers also reflect the common characteristics of datapoints from the same class ( e.g. template face ). Extensive experiments verify the effectiveness and scalability of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a method for domain generalization ( DG ) based on sub - space orientation ( LASSO ). Specifically, instead of constructing a single hypothesis shared among domains, the proposed method explores diverse latent sub - spaces and learns individual hypotheses on those sub - spaces. The proposed method is evaluated on several well - known DG benchmarks and achieves state - of - the - art results.

This paper studies the kernel thinning ( KT ) algorithm of Dwivedi and Mackey ( 2021 ). In particular, the authors propose three new generalizations of the ROOT KT algorithm. The main contribution of the paper is to show that the proposed method can be applied directly to the target RKHS yields tighter, dimension - free guarantees for any kernel, any distribution, and any fixed function in the target Hilbert space. The authors also show that, for analytic kernels like Gaussian, inverse multiquadric, and sinc, target KT admits maximum mean discrepancy ( MMD ) guarantees comparable to or better than those of square - root KT without making explicit use of a square root kernel. Finally, they establish that KT applied to a sum of the target and power kernels simultaneously inherits the improved MMD guarantees of power KT and the tighter individual function guarantees of target KT.

This paper presents an open - source benchmark suite for the MAXIMUM INDEPENDENT SET problem, in both its weighted and unweighted variants. The suite offers a unified interface to various state - of - the - art traditional and machine learning - based solvers. The authors conduct an in - depth analysis of the popular guided tree search algorithm by Li et al. ( 2018 ) by re - implementing their algorithm with a focus on code quality and extensibility. They show that the graph convolution network used in the tree search does not learn a meaningful representation of the solution structure, and can be replaced by random values.

This paper proposes Wavelet Compressed Convolution ( WCC ) to reduce the memory bandwidth and computational cost of image - to - image CNNs. The authors use a hardware - friendly Haar - wavelet transform, known for its effectiveness in image compression, and define the convolution on the compressed activation map. By combining WCC with light quantization, they show that they achieve compression rates equal to 2 - bit and 1 - bit with minimal degradation in image -to - image tasks.

This paper studies the problem of estimating correlated and coarse correlated equilibria in extensive - form games. The authors propose a new algorithm for estimating the correlated distribution of play in an O(T 3/4)-approximate EFCE, which is faster than the best prior rate of $ O(1/2)$. The authors also provide a theoretical analysis of the stability of certain fixed point strategies through a refined perturbation analysis of a structured Markov chain.

This paper proposes a method to learn a discretization of continuous action spaces by leveraging the priors of demonstrations. The proposed method is evaluated on three downstream tasks : Reinforcement Learning with demonstrations, Reinforcement learning with play data, and Imitation Learning. Experiments show that the proposed method outperforms state - of - the - art continuous control methods on a variety of hard manipulation tasks.

This paper presents a novel approach for domain generalization in semantic segmentation. The authors propose a novel adversarial style augmentation ( AdvStyle ) approach, which can dynamically generate hard stylized images during training and thus can effectively prevent the model from overfitting on the source domain. Experiments on two synthetic - to - real datasets demonstrate that AdvStyle can significantly improve the model performance on unseen real domains.

This paper presents a novel approach to learn a latent representation of mid - air gesture data from a Dynamic Vision Sensor ( DVS ). The proposed method is based on an event - based guided variational autoencoder ( VAE ), which encodes the DVS data into a latent space representation and uses it to compute the similarity of the two data points. The authors show that the proposed method achieves 87 % classification accuracy on DVSGesture dataset and can encode the sparse, noisy inputs into an interpretable latent representation, visualized through T - SNE plots.

This paper proposes a method for tabular data classification and regression based on ferns. The proposed method is based on a sparse hierarchical table ensemble ( S - HTE ) architecture, where each fern has a single active word, and each word is used to compute a sparse bit function, which is then used to predict the final output of the fern. The method is evaluated on CIFAR-10 and MNIST datasets, where it is shown to outperform the baselines.

This paper proposes a method for learning value functions from undirected state - only experience ( without action labels ). The authors show that tabular Q - learning in discrete Markov decision processes ( MDPs ) learns the same value function under any arbitrary refinement of the action space. This theoretical result motivates the design of Latent Action Q - Learning ( LAQ ), an offline RL method that can learn effective value functions. The proposed method outperforms imitation learning and imitation learning oracles.

This paper proposes a model - parallel training algorithm for large models with large parameters. The proposed method is based on the Square - Cube Law of distributed training. The authors propose to train a large Transformer language model with 1.1 B shared parameters ( before sharing ) on a swarm of preemptible T4 GPUs with less than 400 Mb/s network throughput. The paper also proposes compression - aware architecture modifications and evaluate their tradeoffs.

This paper proposes a method for offline decentralized multi - agent reinforcement learning ( D4RL ). The proposed method is based on the idea of online transition correction ( OTC ), which aims to correct the biased transition dynamics by modifying sampling probabilities. OTC consists of two types of distances, i.e., embedding - based and value - based distance, to measure the similarity between transitions, and an adaptive rank - based prioritization to sample transitions according to the transition similarity. Empirical results show that OTC outperforms baselines in a variety of tasks.

This paper proposes a new method for quantizing the forward and backward phase of neural networks. The proposed method is based on a logarithmic unbiased quantization ( LUQ ) method and achieves state - of - the - art results in 4 - bit training of ResNet50 on ImageNet. The authors also propose a method that avoids multiplications during two - thirds of the training process, thus reducing by 5x the area used by the multiplier.

This paper studies the problem of meta - learning in the polythetic setting. In particular, the authors argue that there is a difference between monothetic and polythety classifications. They show that threshold classifiers require an embedding space that is exponential in the number of active features and that attentional classifiers are overly sensitive and susceptible to misclassification. To address this, they propose a self - attention feature - selection mechanism that adaptively dilutes non - discriminative features. They demonstrate the effectiveness of their approach in synthetic and real - world few - shot learning tasks.

This paper presents a method to study emergent communication between agents using reinforcement learning. The authors use a simple messaging environment where a “ speaker ” and “ listener ” are trained to communicate over a lossy continuous channel. The speaker is equipped with a vocoder that maps symbols to a continuous waveform, and the Listener needs to map the continuous signal to the concept. Using deep Q - learning, they show that basic compositionality emerges in the learned language representations. They also show that noise is essential in the communication channel when conveying unseen concept combinations.

This paper proposes a novel backdoor attack to attack pre - trained NLP models. The authors propose BadPre, a novel task - agnostic backdoor attack that does not need any prior knowledge about the downstream tasks for embedding backdoors in the models. They design a twostage algorithm to backdoor downstream language models more efficiently. They also design a simple and effective trigger insertion strategy to evade a state - of - the - art backdoor detection method.

This paper proposes a method to learn skills incrementally in an unsupervised manner. The proposed method is based on the idea of incremental skill discovery, where skills are learned one after another in an incremental fashion. The method is evaluated in both static and evolving environments, and is shown to outperform state - of - the - art skill discovery methods on both skill quality and the ability to solve downstream tasks.

This paper proposes a novel log - polar space convolution ( LPSC ) layer, where the convolution kernel is elliptical and adaptively divides its local receptive field into different regions according to the relative directions and logarithmic distances. The LRF grows exponentially with the number of distance levels. The proposed method can be implemented with conventional convolution via log - polarized space pooling and separable center pixel convolution. Experiments on different tasks and datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new information bottleneck based on the PAC - Bayes generalization guarantee ( IIW ), i.e., information stored in weights ( I(w;S ) ), where S = {Xi, Yi } = 1 is a finite - sample dataset. The paper proposes an algorithm for the efficient approximation of IIW, which is based on an information bottleneck on the trade - off between accuracy and information complexity of NNs, namely PIB.   The paper empirically demonstrates the fitting to compressing phase transition during NNs ’ training and the concrete connection between the IIW compression and the generalization gap.

Data poisoning attacks add imperceptible perturbations to training data to maximize the test error. In this paper, the authors investigate why these attacks work in principle. They show that the perturbation of advanced attacks are almost linear separable when assigned with the target labels of the corresponding samples. They further confirm that linear separability is indeed the workhorse for recent attacks. The authors also show that pre - trained feature extractors can be a powerful defense.

This paper proposes a new algorithm for offline policy evaluation based on importance sampling. The main idea is to constrain the potential action set to the set of observed actions with similar states to prevent improper avoidance to lower - reward initial states. The paper provides a theoretical justification of the proposed algorithm through a better per - state - neighborhood normalization condition and shows the limitation of previous attempts to this approach through an illustrative example. The experiments show the proposed method with less overfitting and better test performance compared with state - of - the - art batch RL algorithms.

This paper presents a method for continual learning of how language is grounded in vision. Given a pre - trained multimodal embedding model, where language and images are projected in the same semantic space ( in this case CLIP by OpenAI ), CoLLIE learns a transformation function that adjusts the language embeddings when needed to accommodate new language use. Unlike traditional few - shot learning, the model does not just learn new classes and labels, but can also generalize to similar language use, and benefit from the semantic compositionality of language.

This paper proposes a novel object captioning ( NOC ) model for NOC. NOC is the task of learning a caption for an image that contains a novel image ( i.e., the image does not contain any caption annotations ). The authors propose a novel model based on VLAF2 ( Visual - linguistic Adequacy, Fidelity, and Fluency ), which is a combination of BERT and CLIP - based reinforcement learning. The proposed model is evaluated on the nocaps dataset and achieves SOTA and SPICE scores.

This paper studies the phenomenon of neural collapse, which is the phenomenon that the features learned by overparameterized classification networks show an interesting clustering property, called neural collapse. The authors show that neural collapse generalizes to new samples from the training classes, and – more importantly – to new classes as well, allowing foundation models to provide feature maps that work well in transfer learning and, specifically, in the few - shot setting.

This paper proposes a method for point cloud reconstruction. The method consists of two stages : ( 1 ) a sparse stacked - hourglass network for initial densification and denoising, and ( 2 ) a refinement via transformers converting the discrete voxels into 3D points. The proposed method achieves state - of - the - art performance in the ScanNet, ICL - NUIM, and ShapeNet datasets.

This paper proposes a new method for efficient full - graph GCN training. The main idea is to use inter - partition communication with intra - partition computation to hide the substantial communication overhead. The paper provides a theoretical convergence guarantee and shows the convergence rate of PipeGCN to be close to that of the vanilla distributed GCNs training without staleness. Extensive experiments show that the proposed method can largely boost training throughput while achieving the same accuracy.

This paper proposes a method for test - time adaptation, i.e., using the test input to improve model robustness. The authors propose a simple approach that can be used in any test setting where the model is probabilistic and adaptable : when presented with a test example, perform different data augmentations on the data point, and then adapt ( all of ) the model parameters by minimizing the entropy of the model ’s average, or marginal, output distribution across the augmentations. This objective encourages the model to make the same prediction across different augmentations, thus enforcing the invariances encoded in these augmentations while also maintaining confidence in its predictions.

This paper proposes a new algorithm for model - based reinforcement learning. The main idea is to jointly train the model and the policy, such that updates to either component increase a lower bound on expected return. This joint optimization mends the objective mismatch in prior work. The proposed algorithm ( MnM ) is conceptually similar to a GAN : a classifier distinguishes between real and fake transitions, the model is updated to produce transitions that look realistic, and the policies are updated to avoid states where the model predictions are unrealistic.

This paper proposes a method to solve the problem of imitation learning in partially observed settings. The authors propose a simple model combination approach inspired by human decision making : first compute a coarse action based on the instantaneous observation, and then refine it into a final action using historical information. Experiments show that the proposed method outperforms other baselines on CARLA autonomous driving from images and various MuJoCo continuous control tasks.

This paper proposes a model - based meta - learning method called DyAd to forecast physical dynamics. DyAd uses an encoder to infer the parameters of the task and a prediction network to adapt and forecast given the inferred task. Theoretically, the generalization error of such procedure is related to the task relatedness in the source domain, as well as the domain differences between source and target domains. Experiments are conducted on turbulent flow prediction and real - world ocean temperature forecasting tasks.

This paper proposes a novel method for weakly supervised monocular 3D object detection. The proposed method first generates 2D boxes on the image and uses them to select corresponding RoI LiDAR points as the weak supervision. Then, a network is trained to predict 3D boxes which can tightly align with associated RoI points. This network is learned by minimizing the 3D alignment loss between the 2D box estimates and the corresponding Roi LiDar points.

This paper proposes a new model architecture that learns a subword tokenization end - to - end as part of the model. To this end, the authors introduce a soft gradient - based subword tokensization module ( GBST ) that automatically learns latent subword representations from characters in a data - driven fashion using a block scoring network. Experiments on English GLUE, multilingual, and noisy text datasets show that the proposed model outperforms a series of competitive byte - level baselines.

This paper proposes a method to detect backdoors in black - box neural networks. The proposed method is based on an adversarial extreme value analysis ( AEVA ) algorithm. The authors show that a singularity is often observed in the adversarial map of a backdoorinfected example, which they call adversarial singularity phenomenon. They evaluate the proposed method on three widely - adopted tasks with different backdoor trigger implementations and complex backdoor attack variants.

This paper proposes a new measure for classifier uncertainty estimation based on the Kullback - leibler divergence ( KLoS ) between the predicted Dirichlet distribution and a class - wise prototype Dirchlet distribution. The proposed measure is based on a class-wise divergence measure built from in - distribution samples and does not require OOD training data, in contrast to current second - order uncertainty measures. An auxiliary neural network is also proposed to learn a refined criterion directly aligned with the evidential training objective. Experiments show that the proposed method is more robust to the choice of OOD data.

This paper studies a semi - supervised learning algorithm that learns a linear classifier over features obtained from unlabeled data. The authors assume that the distribution of “ important ” patches in the input images has a low - dimensional structure ( e.g., when the patches are sampled from a low dimensional manifold ). They show that the dependence of the algorithm on the dimension of the patch distribution is essentially optimal, i.e., any learning algorithm must depend on this number.

This paper proposes a novel algorithm for face clustering based on Graph Convolutional Networks ( GCN ). The proposed method first transforms the face into a new structure space, obtaining robust features by considering face features of the neighbour images. Then, an adaptive neighbour discovery strategy is proposed to determine a proper number of edges connecting to each face image. Experiments on multiple public clustering datasets show that Ada - NETS significantly outperforms current state - of - the - art methods.

This paper proposes a new method for generalizable person re - identification ( DG ReID ). The proposed method is based on distributionally robust optimization ( DRO ), where the loss minimizes the loss over a reweighted dataset where important samples ( i.e., samples on which models perform poorly ) will be upweighted and others will be downweighted. Empirical results show that Unit DRO achieves superior performance on large - scale DG Re ID and cross - domain ReID benchmarks compared to standard baselines.

This paper proposes a new regularization method for GNNs to improve over - smoothing. The authors propose to corrupt the input graph with noise, and add a noise correcting node - level loss. They show the effectiveness of the proposed method on three benchmark datasets : OC20 Is2RE, OC20 IS2RS, and QM9.

This paper presents a new approach to the set2vec problem, which is the task of extracting a vector representation from an input set comprised of a variable number of feature vectors. The authors propose to use ExpectationMaximization ( EM ) to estimate the maximum - a - posterior ( MAP ) estimate of the mixture which is approximately attained by a few Expectation - Maximization steps. The whole MAP - EM steps are differentiable operations with a fixed number of mixture parameters, allowing efficient auto -diff backpropagation for any given downstream task. The proposed method is evaluated on various tasks in bioinformatics and NLP.

This paper presents a method for unsupervised feature selection in contrastive analysis ( CA ) setting. The authors propose a method called CFS ( Contrastive Feature Selection ) to select a small number of informative features for use in unknown downstream tasks. The proposed method is evaluated on a semi - synthetic dataset and four real - world biomedical datasets and it consistently outperforms previous state - of - the - art methods.

This paper studies the relationship between optimal early stopping time and model dimension as well as sample size of the dataset for certain linear regression models. The authors show that in common deep learning tasks, the dimension of the model often exceeds the number of features arising from data. They also study the effect of early stopping on generalization and demonstrate that it can help mitigate double descent in various settings.

This paper proposes a quasi - Newton method for the policy gradient algorithm with entropy regularization. In the case of Shannon entropy, the resulting algorithm reproduces the natural policy gradient ( NPG ) algorithm. For other entropy functions, this method results in brand new policy gradient algorithms. The authors provide a simple proof that all these algorithms enjoy the Newton - type quadratic convergence near the optimal policy.

This paper proposes a novel approach to tackle the problem of generalization in text - based games ( TBGs ). The authors propose to use case - based reasoning ( CBR ) to train agents to generalize out of the training distribution. In particular, they propose to collect instances of positive experiences from the agent ’s interaction with the world in the past and later reuses the collected experiences to act efficiently. Experiments show that the proposed approach consistently improves existing methods, obtains good out - of - distribution generalization, and achieves new state - of the - art results on widely used environments.

This paper proposes a two - stage method to distill multiple word senses from a pre - trained contextual language model ( BERT ) by using attention over the senses of a word in a context and transferring this sense information to fit multi - sense embeddings in a skip - gram - like framework. The proposed method is evaluated on the contextual word similarity and sense induction tasks. Experiments show that this method is superior to or competitive with state - of - the - art methods on multiple benchmark data sets.

This paper presents a method to transfer image - pretrained convolutional neural networks to understand 3D point clouds. The authors propose to use the same architecture and pretrained weights of a neural net model to understand both images and point cloud. They do so by inflating 2D convolutionsal filters to 3D convolution filters and finetuning the inflated imagepretrained models ( FIP ). They show that the method can achieve competitive performance on point cloud classification tasks. They also show that it can speed up training of point cloud models.

This paper proposes a method for training autoregressive generative models. The proposed method is based on energy - based learning objective. The authors show that their method is capable of alleviating the exposure bias problem and increase temporal coherence by imposing a constraint which fits joint distributions at each time step. Finally, thanks to importance sampling, they can train the entire model efficiently without requiring an MCMC process.

This paper presents a unified framework that connects Wasserstein distributional robustness with current state - of - the - art adversarial training ( AT ) methods. The authors introduce a new family of risk functions, with which they show that standard AT methods are special cases of their counterparts in their framework. Extensive experiments show that the proposed algorithms are able to boost the model robustness against strong attacks with better generalization capacity.

This paper proposes a novel method for unsupervised representation learning for multivariate time series. The proposed method is based on the idea of instance - level augmentation. The authors propose to use the entire time series as input and apply dropout to generate different views for training. Experiments are conducted on three major practical tasks for time series such as classification, forecasting and anomaly detection.

This paper proposes an algorithm for automatically adjusting the learning rate during gradient descent. The learning rate is optimized via a simple extra gradient descent step, justified by an analysis that exploits the structure of neural networks. The authors formulate first and second - order gradients with respect to learning rate as functions of consecutive weight gradients, leading to a cost - efficient implementation. Extensive experimental evaluation is conducted, validating the effectiveness of the proposed method for a plethora of different settings.

This paper proposes a new method for continual meta - reinforcement learning, where the goal is to achieve high reward over any sequence of tasks quickly. The authors propose a meta - policy search ( CoMPS ) method to address this problem by meta - training in an incremental fashion, over each task in a sequence, without revisiting prior tasks. The proposed method consists of two subroutines : learning a new task using RL and using the experience from RL to perform completely offline meta - learning to prepare for subsequent task learning. The experiments show that the proposed method outperforms other methods on several sequences of challenging continuous control tasks.

This paper proposes a new threat model for poisoned classifiers, where one without knowledge of the original trigger would want to control the poisoned classifier. Under this threat model, the authors propose a test - time, human - in - the - loop attack method to generate multiple effective alternative triggers without access to the initial trigger and the training data. Experiments on ImageNet and TrojAI show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new method for distillation of GANs. The authors claim that the main challenge of unconditional GAN distillation lies in the output discrepancy issue, where the teacher and student model yield different outputs given the same input latent code. They conduct thorough analysis about the reasons and effects of this discrepancy issue and identify that the style module plays a vital role in determining semantic information of generated images. Based on this finding, they propose a novel initialization strategy for the student model, which can ensure the output consistency to the maximum extent. They also propose a latent - direction - based distillation loss that preserves the semantic relations in latent space.

This paper proposes a method for learning offline algorithms in an online setting. The proposed method is based on the notion of behavioral structures in characterizing offline algorithms. The authors propose to use these behavioral structures to generate descriptive labels and then formulate the machine learning problem in those terms. Experiments on synthetic data and historical stock market data demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a method to reduce the training cost of Gaussian processes ( GP ) by amortizing the computation of the inducing points locations and the parameters of the variational posterior approximation of the posterior of the process. The method is based on a neural network architecture that receives the observed data as an input and outputs the inducing point locations and parameters of an approximate posterior distribution q. The paper shows that the proposed method is able to perform similar or better than standard sparse GP and competitive methods for improving the cost of sparse GPs.

This paper proposes a new protocol for secure ( byzantinetolerant ) decentralized training that emphasizes communication efficiency. The authors provide theoretical bounds for its resistance against Byzantine and Sybil attacks and show that it has a marginal communication overhead. They conduct large - scale experiments on image classification and language modeling in presence of Byzantine attackers to verify the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new method for learning particle hydrodynamics ( SPH ) - based models of turbulence. The proposed method is based on the mesh - free Lagrangian formulation of SPH. The authors propose to learn a hierarchy of parameterized and “ physics - explainable ” SPH - informed fluid simulators using both physics - based parameters and Neural Networks as universal function approximators. They show that their method is capable of solving inverse problems over the physically interpretable parameter space, as well as over the space of Neural Network parameters. They also show that adding physical structure improves interpretability, generalizability, preservation of physical symmetries, and requires less training data.

This paper proposes an approach to regularize a single deterministic neural network to obtain improved accuracy and reliable uncertainty estimates. The authors propose Mix - MaxEnt, which is an entropy maximization regularizer corresponding to the predictive distribution in the regions of the embedding space between the class clusters. This is achieved by synthetically generating between - cluster samples via the convex combination of two images from different classes and maximizing the entropy on these samples. Experiments on real - world datasets ( CIFAR-10 and CIFar-100 ) using ResNet and Wide - ResNet architectures demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

This paper proposes a novel method for image animation. The proposed method is based on a self - supervised autoencoder, which learns a set of orthogonal motion directions in the latent space, and uses their linear combination in order to represent any displacement in latent space. The method is evaluated on VoxCeleb, Taichi and TED - talk datasets w.r.t. generated quality.

This paper proposes a method for meta - learning with task interpolation ( MLTI ) to generate additional tasks by randomly sampling a pair of tasks and interpolating the corresponding features and labels. Theoretical analysis shows that MLTI corresponds to a data - adaptive meta - regularization and further improves the generalization. Empirically, the proposed method is shown to outperform the baselines on eight datasets from diverse domains.

This paper proposes a new method for fair representation learning based on normalizing flows ( FNF ). In particular, the authors propose to model the encoder as a normalizing flow trained to minimize the statistical distance between the latent representations of different groups. The main advantage of FNF is that its exact likelihood computation allows us to obtain guarantees on the maximum unfairness of any potentially adversarial downstream predictor. Empirical evaluation on several datasets shows that FNF effectively enforces fairness without significantly sacrificing utility.

This paper proposes a novel GNN called COUNT - GNN to solve the problem of subgraph isomorphism counting on labeled graphs. The key idea is to use edge - centric message passing and query - conditioned graph modulation to improve structure matching between the query and input graphs. Extensive experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a method for federated learning where the clients have their own personalized labels, which might not be compatible with others ( even for the same class ), and can be also possibly from a variety of multiple domains. The authors propose a novel method, namely Agnostic Personalized Federated Learning ( APFL ), where any clients, regardless of what they have learned with their personalized labels can collaboratively learn while benefiting each other. The proposed method measures task - level similarity based on locally learned knowledge and matches the relevant ones for personalized knowledge reflection. Furthermore, the authors factorize the model parameters into two basis vectors and the highly sparse masks to significantly reduce the dimensionlaity of parameter space for alleviating knowledge collapse.

This paper presents an unsupervised learning framework ODDN, a novel approach to decompose temporal scene of multiple objects with dynamics and interactions. It distills disentangled object dynamics which are significant in downstream video reasoning task and also models object interactions which endows the model with the capability of predicting future frames. The proposed method is evaluated on video understanding and video prediction tasks.

Graph neural networks ( GNN ) have shown great advantages in many graph - based learning tasks but often fail to predict accurately for a task based on sets of nodes such as link/motif prediction and so on. In this work, the authors revisit GNNs that allow using positional features of nodes given by positional encoding ( PE ) techniques such as Laplacian Eigenmap, Deepwalk, etc. The authors study these issues in a principled way and propose a class of GNN layers termed PEG with rigorous mathematical analysis. Extensive link prediction experiments over 8 real - world networks demonstrate the advantages of PEG in generalization and scalability.

This paper proposes LaMer, a novel text style transfer framework based on large - scale language models. LaMer first mines the roughly parallel expressions in the non - parallel datasets with scene graphs, and then employs MLE training, followed by imitation learning refinement to leverage the intrinsic parallelism within the data. On two benchmark tasks (sentiment & formality transfer ) and a newly proposed challenging task ( political stance transfer ), LaMer achieves qualitative advances in transfer accuracy, content preservation, and fluency.

This paper studies the problem of multi - hop logical reasoning on hyper - relational knowledge graphs ( KGs ). In particular, the authors propose a method to embed and answer conjunctive queries in latent space. The proposed method is based on Graph Neural Networks ( GNNs ) and uses a subset of first - order logic ( FOL ) well - explored in the literature. Experiments are conducted to show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new Bayesian optimization method for hyperparameter optimization ( HPO ) in the gray - box setting. The authors propose a new surrogate for Gaussian Processes that embeds the learning curve dynamics and a new acquisition function that incorporates multi - budget information. The proposed method is evaluated on 50 datasets ( Tabular, Image, NLP ) and diverse neural networks ( MLP, CNN/NAS, RNN ).

This paper studies the problem of cross - platform consistency in learned image compression. The authors propose to solve this problem by introducing well - developed post - training quantization and making the model inference integer - arithmetic - only. They further improve the discretization of the entropy parameters and extend the deterministic inference to fit Gaussian mixture models. They show that the current state - of - the - art image compression models can infer in a cross - platforms consistent manner.

This paper proposes an unsupervised noise reconstruction and removal network for denoising scanning electron microscopy images. The architecture is inspired by gated recurrent units and reconstructs and removes the noise by synthesizing the sequential data. At the same time, the network is trained on the data to distinguish true signal from noise and gives comparable or even better results than supervised approaches.

Graph neural networks ( GNNs ) and label propagation ( LPs ) are two interrelated methods to model graph structure. The authors propose to use a randomly - selected portion of the training labels as GNN inputs, concatenating with the original node features for making predictions on the remaining labels. This so - called label trick accommodates the parallel use of features and labels and is foundational to many of the top - ranking submissions on the Open Graph Benchmark ( OGB ) leaderboard.   The authors prove that under certain simplifying assumptions, the stochastic label trick can be reduced to an interpretable, deterministic training objective composed of two factors. The first is a data - fitting term that naturally resolves potential label leakage issues, while the second serves as a regularization factor conditioned on graph structure that adapts to graph size and connectivity.

This paper proposes to model machine theory of mind ( ToM ) in a more flexible and symmetric scenario where all agents can speak, listen, see other agents, and move freely through a grid world in a multi - agent SymmToM setting. The authors provide a framework to analyze the problem in a symmetric setting, a more realistic setup than the tasks currently used in the community. They provide a simplified setup on which to test the problem, and they show that even with this minimal set of rules, SymToM proves algorithmically difficult for current multi - Agent deep reinforcement learning models, even when tailoring them to our specific task.

This paper proposes a novel method for zero - shot object detection. The proposed method is based on a modified YOLOv5 neural network to perform generalized zeroshot detection on seen and unseen objects. The authors also propose a novel splitting method for YCB Video dataset to train and test gZSD algorithms.

This paper presents a method for generating high - resolution and high - fidelity videos. The proposed method is based on pre - training an image generator model, followed by learning an autoregressive prediction model in the latent space of the image generator. The authors show that the proposed method achieves competitive performance to state - of - the - art approaches on standard video prediction benchmarks with fewer parameters and enables high resolution video prediction on complex datasets.

This paper proposes a novel GAN architecture based on vision transformers ( ViTs ) for image generation. The proposed method is evaluated on three image recognition benchmarks. The authors claim that the proposed method achieves comparable performance to the best CNN - based GAN models on CIFAR-10, CelebA, and LSUN bedroom.

This paper studies the problem of image generative modeling with variational autoencoders. The authors propose a two - stage training procedure that prioritizes the modeling the perceptible information over the non - perceptible bits in order to achieve good sample quality. They also propose a secondary high - rate model that is trained on top of the low - rate models to improve ELBO.

This paper proposes a method to estimate the optimal reverse variance and the optimal KL divergence of a DPM using a Monte Carlo method and a score - based model. The authors show that both the optimal variance and optimal divergence have analytic forms w.r.t. its score function. To correct the potential bias caused by the score based model, the authors derive both lower and upper bounds of the optimal inverse variance and clip the estimate for a better result. Empirically, the proposed method is shown to improve the log - likelihood of various DPMs.

This paper studies the performance of vision transformers ( ViTs ) on medical image classification and segmentation tasks. The authors conduct a series of experiments on several standard medical image benchmark datasets and tasks. They show that, while CNNs perform better if trained from scratch, ViTs can perform on par with CNNs when pretrained on ImageNet, both in a supervised and self - supervised setting.

This paper studies the problem of how to design training examples for neural language models ( NLM ). In particular, the authors argue that the training examples should be composed of contiguous text segments of sizes processable by the neural architecture. They show that this is not always the best way to do so. They argue that there is a " depth deficit " of 6 layers for modeling dependencies between sentences that are not seen in the same training example. They also show that including semantically related non - related sentences in the training example yields improved sentence representations and open domain question answering abilities.

This paper proposes a new method for learning to optimize ( L2O ) based on symbolic regression.
