The experimental results confirm the practical viability of the method and show that it outperforms a leading commercial optimization package by several orders of magnitude.

This paper studies the online knapsack problem with very weak predictions. The authors derive online algorithms that attain the best possible competitive ratio for any fixed prediction. They also extend the results to more general settings such as generalized one - way trading and two - stage onlineknapsack.

This paper proposes a new model - based episodic memory of trajectories to address the limitations of episodic control. The memory estimates trajectory values, guiding the agent towards good policies. Experiments demonstrate that the model allows significantly faster and better learning than other strong reinforcement learning agents across a variety of environments including stochastic and non - Markovian settings.

This paper proposes a new semi - supervised learning method DP - SSL to generate probabilistic labels for unlabeled data. The proposed method is based on multiple - choice learning ( MCL ) based approach to automatically generate LFs from scratch in SSL style. With the noisy labels produced by the LFs, a label model is trained to resolve the conflict and overlap among the noisy labeled, and finally infer the labels. Extensive experiments on four standard SSL benchmarks show that DP -SSL can provide reliable labels and achieve better classification performance on test sets than existing SSL methods.

This paper presents a method for estimating multi - person 3D poses from multi - view images. The proposed method is based on a direct regression approach to estimate the 3D joint locations. The method is evaluated on the Panoptic dataset and achieves state - of - the - art results.

This paper studies the problem of recovering the support of a family of unknown sparse vectors from a sequence of noisy responses. In particular, the authors consider the case where the family has at most k non - zero elements, and each response shows the sign of the inner product between a randomly chosen vector from the family and the query vector. The authors propose two learning algorithms for the first problem, one for the support recovery problem and the other for the approximate recovery problem.   The authors show that the first algorithm is robust to noisy responses, and the second algorithm can be robust to error - free responses.

This paper studies the problem of changepoint detection in the bandit setting, where only a small subset of sensors are used to detect abrupt changes in temporal behavior patterns. The authors derive an information - theoretic lower bound on the detection delay for a general class of finitely parameterized probability distributions. They then propose a computationally efficient online sensing scheme, which seamlessly balances the need for exploration of different sensing options with exploitation of querying informative actions. They derive expected delay bounds for the proposed scheme and show that these bounds match their information - theoretic lower bounds at low false alarm rates.

This paper proposes a new algorithm for solving stochastic nested optimization problems. The main contribution of the paper is a tighter analysis of ALSET for solving nested nested problems. Under the new analysis, to achieve an - stationary point of the nested problem, it requires O( -2 ) samples in total. The algorithm is applied to the bilevel, min - max, and reinforcement learning problems.

This paper presents a method for video question answering ( VideoQA ). The authors propose a Siamese Sampling and Reasoning ( SiaSamRea ) approach, which consists of a siamese sampling mechanism to generate sparse and similar clips from the same video, and a novel reasoning strategy for integrating the interdependent knowledge between contextual clips into the network. Extensive experiments demonstrate that the proposed method achieves state - of - the - art performance on five video QA benchmarks.

This paper proposes a method to reduce the computational and memory complexity of a large class of structured models by using a low - rank constraint to trade off model expressivity and speed via the rank of the matrix - product.   The authors show that by viewing the central inference step as a matrix - vector product, they can trade off the expressivity of a model and the speed of inference. The authors propose to use a mixed parameterization of every scoring matrix in the model to limit the computational complexity of the model. They show that they can achieve this by treating the emission probabilities p(xt | zt ) as constants, and absorb them into cu(TLN ).

This paper proposes a simple and efficient uncertainty measure to estimate the uncertainty of the outcomes in a contextual bandit problem. The proposed method is based on a Bayesian approach that directly estimates the uncertainty based on the value predictions. The authors show theoretically that the uncertainty measure estimated by SAU asymptotically matches the uncertainty provided by Thompson Sampling, as well as its regret bounds. Empirically, the proposed method outperforms the state - of - the - art deep Bayesian bandit methods on several real - world datasets at modest computation cost.

This paper proposes a method for unsupervised behavior representation learning from multisession videos. The proposed method disentangles the dynamic behavioral factors ( pose ) from time - invariant, non - behavioral nuisance factors ( context ) in a deep autoencoder and exploit the temporal structures of pose dynamics. Compared to competing approaches, DBE and VDBE enjoy superior performance on downstream tasks such as fine - grained behavioral motif generation and behavior decoding.

This paper proposes a new method for conditional 3D shape synthesis from coarse voxels. The proposed method combines implicit and explicit 3D representations by leveraging a deformable tetrahedral grid that encodes a discretized signed distance function and a differentiable marching tetrahedra layer that converts the implicit signed distance representation to the explicit surface mesh representation. Experiments show that the proposed method achieves better reconstruction quality than state - of - the - art methods, while requiring a lower computation cost.

This paper proposes sliced mutual information ( SMI ) as a surrogate measure of dependence. SMI is defined as an average of MI terms between one - dimensional random projections. The authors show that SMI preserves many of the structural properties of classic mutual information, while gaining scalable computation and efficient estimation from samples. Experiments validate the theoretical study.

This paper proposes a two - step lookahead constrained constrained Bayesian optimization acquisition function ( 2 - OPT - C ). The authors argue that being non - myopic is even more important in constrained problems because fear of violating constraints pushes myopic methods away from sampling the boundary between feasible and infeasible regions, slowing the discovery of optimal solutions with tight constraints. In numerical experiments, the proposed method typically improves query efficiency by 2x or more over previous methods, and in some cases by 10x.

This paper proposes a method to model the joint return distribution of multiple reward sources in a value - based reinforcement learning ( RL ) setting. The proposed method is based on the distributional distributional DQN ( MD3QN ) framework, which models the joint distributional Bellman operator of the reward function. The authors show the convergence of the proposed method to the Bellman target by minimizing the Maximum Mean Discrepancy ( MMD ) between the model distribution and the target distribution. Empirically, the authors show that the proposed algorithm can accurately model the return distribution in environments with richly correlated reward functions.

This paper proposes a new method for reconstructing high - resolution, accurate, and regular triangular meshes from volumetric images. The method is based on a flow ODE framework and is trained to deform a reference template towards a targeted object. To reduce topological errors introduced by its discrete resolution, the authors derive numerical conditions to improve the manifoldness of the predicted triangle mesh. Experiments show that the proposed method produces superior surfaces while reducing the computation time from 9.5 minutes to 1 second.

This paper studies the problem of data deletion in the non - convex setting. In particular, the authors consider the case where there is a sequence of deletions that are adaptive to the model used to train the model. In this setting, they show that there is an important blindspot in the data deletion literature ( the tenuous implicit assumption that deletion requests are independent of previously released models ) and provide a very general methodology to reduce adaptive deletion guarantees to oblivious deletion guarantees. Through this reduction they get the first model and training algorithm agnostic methodology that allows for deletion of arbitrary sequences of adaptively chosen points while giving rigorous guarantees.

This paper studies the problem of conditional value at risk ( CVaR ) of the total return in Bayes - adaptive Markov decision processes ( MDPs ). The authors propose an approximate algorithm based on Monte Carlo tree search ( MCTS ) and Bayesian optimisation. They show that the proposed algorithm is risk - averse to both the epistemic uncertainty and the aleatoric uncertainty due to the inherent stochasticity of the MDP. They reformulate the problem as a two - player stochastically game and propose a new algorithm.

This paper studies the behavior of shallow ReLU networks trained with the logistic loss via gradient descent on binary classification data where the underlying data distribution is general, and the ( optimal ) Bayes risk is not necessarily zero. In this setting, it is shown that gradient descent with early stopping achieves population risk arbitrarily close to optimal in terms of logistic and misclassification losses. Moreover, the necessary iteration, sample, and architectural complexities of this analysis all scale naturally with a certain complexity measure of the true conditional model.

This paper proposes a method to detect coordinated groups on social media. The proposed method is based on a prior knowledge guided neural temporal point process with prior knowledge such as temporal logic or pre - defined filtering functions. The authors jointly learn a Gibbs distribution of group assignment based on how consistent an assignment is to ( 1 ) the account embedding space and ( 2 ) the prior knowledge. To address the challenge that the distribution is hard to be efficiently computed and sampled from, the authors propose a theoretically guaranteed variational inference approach to learn a mean - field approximation for it. Experimental results on a real - world dataset show the effectiveness of the proposed method compared to other methods.

This paper studies the problem of binary classification with non - linear structure, i.e., two disjoint smooth curves on the unit sphere. The authors show that when the network depth is large relative to certain geometric properties that set the difficulty of the problem, and the network width and number of samples are polynomially in the depth, randomly - initialized gradient descent quickly learns to correctly classify all points on the two curves with high probability. To their knowledge, this is the first generalization guarantee for deep networks with nonlinear data that depends only on intrinsic data properties.

This paper proposes two new methods to tackle the problem of gradient exploding in the classifier in the early stages of training a GAN. The first method is to project the input vectors onto a unit hypersphere. The second one is to use the data - to - data cross - entropy loss ( D2D - CE ) to exploit the class - labeled dataset. Experiments are conducted on CIFAR10, TinyImageNet, CUB200, and ImageNet datasets to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes an extensive - form double - oracle algorithm for two - player zero - sum games that is guaranteed to converge to an approximate Nash equilibrium linearly in the number of infostates. Unlike PSRO, which mixes best responses at the root of the game, XDO mixes best response at every infostate. In tabular experiments on Leduc poker and Oshi - Zumo, the authors show that tabular XDO achieves a lower exploitability than CFR with the same amount of computation.

This paper proposes a graph - level unsupervised representation learning method for graph structured data. The authors propose a permutation - invariant variational autoencoder to learn to match the node order of input and output graph, without imposing a particular node order or performing expensive graph matching. They demonstrate the effectiveness of their proposed model for graph reconstruction, generation and interpolation and evaluate the expressive power of extracted representations for downstream classification and regression.

This paper proposes a method to improve the expressivity and scalability of graph neural networks ( GNNs ) by first extracting a localized subgraph as the bounded - size scope, and then applying a GNN of arbitrary depth on top of the subgraph. A properly extracted subgraph consists of a small number of critical neighbors, while excluding irrelevant ones. The GNN, no matter how deep it is, smooths the local neighborhood into informative representation rather than oversmoothing the global graph into “ white noise ”. Empirically, the proposed method achieves significant accuracy improvement with orders of magnitude reduction in computation.

This paper studies the problem of universal approximation with well - conditioned affine - coupling networks. In particular, the authors show that any log - concave distribution can be approximated using well - conditioned affine-coupling flows.   The authors also provide a proof of the connection between underdamped Langevin dynamics, Hénon maps, and symplectic diffeomorphisms. The authors use Gaussian padding to approximate the input distribution.

This paper proposes a new method to solve the problem of coupons allocation in the online e - commerce market. The proposed method is based on a budget constrained offline reinforcement learning and evaluation ( BCORLE ) framework. The main contribution of this work is four - fold. First, the proposed method uses a generalization of the Lagrangian multiplier variable ( $ \lambda$ ) to learn the policy. Second, an off - policy evaluation method ( REME ) is proposed to evaluate the performance of learned policy. Third, a batch - constrained Q - learning ( R - BCQ ) method is proposed. Finally, experiments on a simulation platform and a real - world e -commerce market validate the effectiveness of the proposed methods.

This paper proposes a new method for domain adaptation. The proposed method is based on the observation that target data might no longer align with the source domain classifier but still form clear clusters. The authors propose to capture this intrinsic structure by defining local affinity of the target data and encourage label consistency among data with high local affinity. They observe that higher affinity should be assigned to reciprocal neighbors, and propose a self - regularization loss to decrease the negative impact of noisy neighbors. Finally, to aggregate information with more context, they consider expanded neighborhoods.

This paper proposes a method for pooling a set of features into a fixed - dimensional representation based on sliced - Wasserstein distance ( SW ). The proposed method is based on a permutation - invariant backbone, where each element of the set is represented as a probability distribution. The authors show that the proposed method can learn the exact Euclidean embedding for the ( generalized ) ( sliced - wasserstein ) distance between the set elements and a reference set. The method is evaluated on point cloud classification, graph classification, and image classification tasks.

This paper proposes a new family of RNNs, SBO - RNN, that can be formulated using stochastic bilevel optimization ( SBO ) to solve the lower and upper - level optimization for learning hidden states and their hyperparameters, respectively. The authors prove that under mild conditions there is no vanishing or exploding gradient in training SBO-RNN, and thus the training is easy and stabilized. Empirically, the proposed method is shown to achieve better performance on several benchmark datasets, with fewer parameters, less training data and faster convergence.

This paper studies the online problem of minimizing power consumption in systems with multiple power - saving states. The authors develop a learning - augmented online algorithm that makes decisions based on (potentially inaccurate ) predicted lengths of the idle periods. The algorithm ’s performance is near - optimal when predictions are accurate and degrades gracefully with increasing prediction error, with a worst - case guarantee almost identical to the optimal classical online algorithm for the problem.

This paper proposes a mathematical framework for quantifying the transferability in multi - source transfer learning problems, with both the task similarities and the sample complexity of learning models taken into account. In particular, the authors consider the setup where the models learned from different tasks are linearly combined for learning the target task, and use the optimal combining coefficients to measure transferability. Then, they demonstrate the analytical expression of this transferability measure, characterized by the sample sizes, model complexity, and the similarities between source and target tasks, which provides fundamental insights of the knowledge transferring mechanism and the guidance for algorithm designs.

This paper proposes a model for visual search where the goal is to find a target among a set of distractors ( e.g., car keys ). The model is based on the observation that in humans, finding the target among distractors can be easier than finding the distractors among the target. The authors propose a model that takes a target and a search image as inputs and produces a sequence of eye movements until the target is found.   The model integrates eccentricity - dependent visual recognition with target - dependent top - down cues and compares against human behavior in six paradigmatic search tasks that show asymmetry in humans.

This paper studies the problem of training robust models against adversarial examples by minimizing the worst - case loss over the allowed perturbations. The authors claim that the loss landscape is an important factor that influences in building certifiably robust models, and that the current state - of - the - art method often has a landscape with favorable optimization properties. To verify this claim, the authors propose a new certifiable training method with tighter bounds and a favorable loss landscape.

This paper studies the problem of online linear regression in the stochastic setting. The authors derive high probability regret bounds for online ridge regression and the forward algorithm. This enables them to compare online regression algorithms more accurately and eliminate assumptions of bounded observations and predictions. This paper advocates for the use of forward algorithm in lieu of ridge due to its enhanced bounds and robustness to the regularization parameter.

This paper proposes a two - time - scale and anchored extragradient method for smooth structured nonconvex - nonconcave problems. The proposed method has an accelerated O(1/k2 ) rate, with respect to the squared gradient norm, for the Lipschitz continuous and negative comonotone operators for the first time. It also has value for smooth convex - concave problems compared to existing works. The paper further develops its backtracking line - search version, named FEG - A.

This paper studies the problem of uniformity testing for ranking data that consists of rankings over m items, where the alternative class is restricted to Mallows models. The authors show that uniform distribution can be distinguished from Mallows model with O(m 1/2 ) samples based on simple pairwise statistics, which allows us to test uniformity using only two samples, if m is large enough.   The authors also consider uniforming testing with central and local differential privacy ( DP ) constraints. They present a central DP algorithm that requires O(max{1/1/0, 1/ p m} ), where $ \epsilon$ is the privacy budget parameter.

This paper proposes a score - based algorithm for learning directed acyclic graphs. The main contribution of the paper is to study the duality between Bregman divergences and exponential families. The authors show that recent polynomial - time algorithms for learning DAG models are a special case of this algorithm. This observation suggests new score functions and optimality conditions based on duality. The paper also provides extensive experiments suggesting that this algorithm indeed optimizes the score.

This paper proposes a method to improve the adversarial robustness of the backbone CNNs that have a satisfactory accuracy. The authors propose to dilate the architecture of neural networks to increase the adversarially robustness while maintaining a competitive standard accuracy with a straightforward constraint. Theoretical analyses on the standard and adversarial error bounds naturally motivate the proposed neural architecture dilation algorithm. Experimental results on real - world datasets and benchmark neural networks demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm to balance the accuracy and robustness.

This paper studies model - based reward - free reinforcement learning with linear function approximation for episodic Markov decision processes ( MDPs ). The authors propose a new provably efficient algorithm UCRL - RFE under the linear mixture MDP assumption, where the transition probability kernel of the MDP can be parameterized by a linear function over certain feature mappings defined on the triplet of state, action, and next state. They show that to obtain an $ \epsilon$-optimal policy for arbitrary reward function, UCRL-RFE needs to sample at most $ \Omega(\sqrt{H})$ episodes during the exploration phase, where $ H$ is the length of the episode and d is the dimension of the feature mapping. They also propose a variant of the algorithm using Bernstein - type bonus.

This paper proposes a method for forecasting future activities in data streams. The proposed method is based on the Shifting Seasonal Matrix Factorization ( SSMF ) approach, which can adaptively learn multiple seasonal patterns ( called regimes ) as well as switching between them. The method is evaluated on three real - world data streams and is shown to outperform state - of - the - art baselines.

This paper proposes a novel neural network architecture, WeaveNet, to solve the assignment problem. The core module, feature weaving layer, is stacked to model frequent communication between elements in a parameter - efficient way for solving the combinatorial problem of assignment. The experimental results show its impressive performance among the learning - based baselines.

This paper studies the impact of various self - supervised learning proxy tasks on the adversarial robustness of 3D point clouds with adversarial training. The authors show that appropriate applications of self - supervision can significantly enhance the robustness in 3d point cloud recognition. They further leverage two simple yet powerful ensemble methods to boost the adversarially robustness by a substantial margin.

This paper studies the problem of minimizing separable convex functions over submodular base polytopes. In particular, the authors consider iterative projections of close - by points over widely - prevalent sub modular basepolytopes B(f ). They develop a toolkit to speed up the computation of projections using both discrete and continuous perspectives. They then adapt the away - step Frank - Wolfe algorithm to use this information and enable early termination. Theoretical results show orders of magnitude reduction in runtime in some cases.

This paper studies the problem of learning the natural parameters of a k - parameter minimal exponential family from i.i.d samples in a computationally and statistically efficient manner. The authors consider the setting where the support as well as the natural parameter are appropriately bounded. They provide finite sample guarantees to achieve an ( `2 ) error of alpha in the parameter estimation with sample complexity O(poly(k / alpha ) ) and computational complexity $ O(\sqrt(k/alpha)$. They also provide an interpretation of their estimator in terms of a maximum likelihood estimation.

This paper proposes a differentiable renderer for inverse graphics based on differentiable differentiable algorithms. The main contribution of the paper is to propose a hybrid renderer that combines rasterization and ray tracing. The authors propose to use a convolutional neural network F, parameterized by learnable weights ϑ, to predict 3D attributes of a mesh M with pre - determined topology ( spherical in the case ). They then render these parameters back to an image I using their differentiability renderer and apply a loss L on the RGB output to compare the input image I and the rendered image I, where L is the L1 - distance between rendered image and input image.

This paper proposes a differentiable training method that imposes implicit constraints to the shape of the probability map by minimizing the expectation of the localization error. To approximate the expectation, the authors introduce a continuous formulation of the output distribution and develop a sampling process. The expectation can be approximated by calculating the average error of all samples drawn from output distribution. The authors show that the proposed method can seamlessly replace the conventional soft - argmax operation on various localization tasks.

Graph Contrastive Learning ( GCL ) has emerged to learn generalizable representations from contrastive views. In this paper, the authors propose a directed graph data augmentation method called Laplacian perturbation and theoretically analyze how it provides contrastive information without changing the directed graph structure. They also propose a curriculum learning approach to learn from multiple easy - to - difficult contrastive view. They empirically show that their model can retain more structural features of directed graphs than other GCL models because of its ability to provide complete contrastive info.

This paper proposes the Symbolic Interactive Language Grounding benchmark ( SILG ), which unifies a collection of diverse grounded language learning environments under a common interface. The benchmark consists of grid - world environments that require generalization to new dynamics, entities, and partially observed worlds ( RTFM, Messenger, NetHack ), as well as symbolic counterparts of visual worlds that require interpreting rich natural language with respect to complex scenes ( ALFWorld, Touchdown ). In addition, the authors propose the first shared model architecture for RL on these environments, and evaluate recent advances such as egocentric local convolution, recurrent state - tracking, entity - centric attention, and pretrained LM using SILG.

This paper proposes a new method for sparsely - gated Mixture of Experts ( V - MoE ) for image recognition. The proposed method is based on the GShard architecture, which is a distributed version of the Vision Transformer ( ViT ). The authors show that the proposed method can train models with up to 24 MoE layers, 32 experts per layer, and almost 15 B parameters. They show that these models can be stably trained, seamlessly used for transfer, and successfully fine - tuned with as few as 1 000 datapoints.

This paper studies the expressivity and trainability of narrow neural networks. The authors show that as long as the width m > 2n/d ( where d is the input dimension ), there exists at least one global minimizer with zero training loss. They also show that there exists a nice local region with no local - min or saddle points. Finally, they show that every KKT point is a nearly global minimizers.

This paper proposes a continuous mean - covariance bandit ( CMCB ) model for online decision - making with correlated options. The authors propose three feedback settings, i.e., full - information, semi - information and full - bandit feedback, to formulate different real - world reward observation scenarios. They propose algorithms with optimal regrets ( within logarithmic factors ), and provide matching lower bounds to validate their optimalities. The experimental results also demonstrate the superiority of the proposed algorithms.

This paper studies the problem of computing positive semidefinite PSD factorization of a data matrix X with non - negative entries. The authors propose a non - commutative extension of Lee - Seung ’s Multiplicative Update ( MMU ) algorithm to solve the problem. They show that the squared loss objective is non - increasing and fixed points correspond to critical points. They also show the utility of their method with experiments on real and synthetic data.

This paper proposes a meta - domain specific - domain invariant ( mDSDI ) framework for domain generalization. The key insight is to disentangle features in the latent space while jointly learning both domain - invariant and domain - specific features in a unified framework. The proposed method is evaluated on several benchmark datasets, including Colored - MNIST, VLCS, PACS, Office - Home, Terra Incognita, DomainNet and DomainNet.

This paper presents a method to improve the FID of a generative model by using a series of ablations. The method is based on a diffusion model, which is a combination of a GAN and a classifier. The proposed method is evaluated on unconditional image synthesis and conditional image synthesis. The authors show that the proposed method can achieve FIDs of 2.97, 4.59, and 7.72 on ImageNet 128, 256 and 512, respectively.

This paper proposes to leverage out - of - distribution samples, i.e., unlabeled samples coming from outside target classes, for improving few - shot learning. The proposed method is simple to implement, agnostic to feature extractors, lightweight without any additional cost for pre - training, and applicable to both inductive and transductive settings. Extensive experiments on various standard benchmarks demonstrate that the proposed method consistently improves the performance of pretrained networks with different architectures.

This paper studies the problem of prioritized sampling in off - policy reinforcement learning. The authors propose two new methods to compute the prioritization weight, namely ReMERN and ReMERT. Theoretical analysis is provided to explain some of the previous criteria of prioritization, such as TD error, recentness, and corrective feedback, which are mostly heuristically designed. Experiments are conducted on MuJoCo, Atari and Meta - World to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed methods.

This paper studies the problem of sequential prediction with expert advice in a nonstationary environment with long - term memory guarantees in the sense of Bousquet and Warmuth [ 4 ]. The authors propose a linear - time algorithm that improves on the best known regret bounds [ 27 ]. This algorithm incorporates a relative entropy projection step. This projection is advantageous over previous weight - sharing approaches in that weight updates may come with implicit costs.

This paper studies the problem of contextual linear bandits. In this problem, the learner is given a set of actions $ X_t$ of which $ x_t \times R$ is a subset of possible actions $ w_t$. The goal is to learn a hidden d - dimensional value $ w$ of the set $ w_{t}$, where $ w^{-1}$ is the hidden value of the action $ x_{t}\times R$. The learner can either choose a single action $ X_{t\times R}$ to take, or a list of actions that are all $ X$.    The authors consider two variants of the problem. In the first variant, they design algorithms with regret $ O(\sqrt{T})$ and exp(O(\log T)$, and in the second variant they design an algorithm with $ O(log \log T )$ regret.   They also consider a variant where they are allowed to provide a list $ \mathcal{T}$ of actions, and they give an algorithm that achieves regret $ \log O(\log d)$ and list size poly(d)$. Finally, they consider the case where they can only provide a single recommendation.

This paper proposes a method for automating the search space for AutoML optimizers. The proposed method is based on the idea of combinators, which is a powerful concept from functional programming. The authors introduce a small set of orthogonal combinators for composing machine learning operators into pipelines. They also introduce a translation scheme from pipelines and associated hyperparameter schemas to search spaces for auto - learning optimizers, and evaluate it with a user study.

This paper proposes a meta - learning approach to improve the generalization of neural networks. In particular, the authors propose to learn a weight initialization such that a small number of weight changes results in low generalization error. They show that patterned sparsity emerges from this process, with the pattern of sparsity varying on a problem - by - problem basis. This selective sparsity results in better generalization and less interference in a range of few - shot and continual learning problems.

This paper proposes a new method for shared independent component analysis ( ShICA ), which models each view as a linear transform of shared independent components contaminated by additive Gaussian noise. The authors show that this model is identifiable if the components are either non - Gaussian or have enough diversity in noise variances. They show that in some cases multi - set canonical correlation analysis can recover the correct unmixing matrices, but that even a small amount of sampling noise makes Multiset CCA fail. To solve this problem, they propose to use joint diagonalization after multiset correlation analysis to solve the problem. Experiments on fMRI and MEG datasets show that ShICA yields more accurate estimation of the components than alternatives.

This paper proposes a novel method to train agents to play with humans in a two - player collaborative cooking simulator. The authors argue that the crux of the problem is to produce a diverse set of training partners. They propose to train the agent partner as the best response to a population of self - play agents and their past checkpoints taken throughout training, a method they call Fictitious Co - Play ( FCP ). They demonstrate that FCP significantly outperforms the BCP state - of - the - art, both in task score and in human partner preference.

This paper proposes a new method for cooperative multi - agent reinforcement learning in both discrete and continuous action spaces. The proposed method learns a centralised but factored critic, which combines per - agent utilities into the joint action - value function via a non - linear monotonic function, as in QMIX. Unlike QMIx, there are no inherent constraints on factoring the critic. This allows for more coordinated policy changes and fully reaps the benefits of a centralized critic.

This paper proposes a new model for memory - augmented neural networks. The key idea is to use a key - value mechanism to store and read out memories in a single step. The proposed model uses a combination of biologically plausible three - factor plasticity rules. The model is evaluated on auto - associative memory tasks, continual recall, heteroassociative memory, and sequence learning.

This paper studies the problem of online gradient descent for pairwise learning, where the loss function depends on a pair of instances. The main contribution of this paper is to propose a differentially private algorithm for the problem. Theoretical results are provided for convex and nonconvex problems, as well as both smooth and nonsmooth problems. The paper also proposes a novel decomposition to circumvent the standard concentration inequalities.

This paper proposes a new method for reconstructing dynamic objects from videos. The proposed method is based on a canonical 4D implicit function which is pixel - aligned with aggregated temporal visual cues and a 4D transformation module which captures object dynamics to support temporal propagation and aggregation. The authors conduct experiments on synthetic RGBD video datasets SAIL - VOS 3D and DeformingThings4D++ and on real - world video data 3DPW. They find that the proposed method outperforms state - of - the - art dynamic reconstruction methods by a large margin.

This paper provides a non - asymptotic analysis of linear stochastic approximation ( LSA ) algorithms with fixed stepsize. The authors derive high probability bounds on the performance of LSA under weaker conditions on the sequence { ( An,bn ) : n 2 N⇤ } than previous works. They establish polynomial concentration bounds with order depending on the stepsize and show that no Gaussian or exponential high - probability bounds can hold.

This paper extends the options framework for temporal abstraction in reinforcement learning from discounted to average - reward MDPs. The authors propose general convergent off - policy inter - option learning algorithms, intra - option algorithms for learning values and models, as well as sample - based planning variants of the learning algorithms. They also extend the notion of option - interrupting behavior from the discounted to the average reward formulation. They show the efficacy of the proposed algorithms with experiments on a continuing version of the Four - Room domain.

This paper studies the performance of different visual transformers ( VTs ) in a small training set regime. It shows that the performance on small datasets can be largely different from that of larger datasets. To this end, it proposes an auxiliary self - supervised task which can extract additional information from images with only a negligible computational overhead. This task encourages the VTs to learn spatial relations within an image and makes the VT training much more robust when training data is scarce.

This paper proposes a new method for label - free alignment of hierarchical data in the hyperboloid space. The proposed method is based on the Riemannian geometry of the Lorentz model of hyperbolic space and consists of the three prototypical Procrustes analysis components : translation, scaling, and rotation. The authors analyze the proposed components, highlighting their useful properties for alignment. The efficacy of the proposed method, its theoretical properties, stability and computational efficiency are demonstrated in simulations.

This paper studies the trade - off between accuracy for a population of interest ( “ sum query ” ) vs. accuracy for its component subpopulations ( ‘ point queries ’ ). The authors show that for pure differential privacy, without the microdata requirement, one can provide noisy answers to the sum query and all point queries while guaranteeing that each answer has squared error O(1 / d ). With the micro data requirement, they show that one must choose between allowing an additional log(d ) factor ( d is the number of point queries ) for some point queries or allowing an extra O(d) factor for the sum queries. They present lower bounds for pure, approximate, and concentrated differential privacy. They propose mitigation strategies and create a collection of benchmark datasets that can be used for public study.

This paper proposes a new framework for learning from each other in goal - conditioned reinforcement learning ( RL ) and planning ( PPO ). In particular, the authors propose to learn a curriculum of tree - structured sub - tasks, where the planner decomposes a long - horizon task to a tree of sub - tasks in a top - down manner, whose layers construct coarse - to - fine sub - task sequences as plans to complete the original task. The planning policy is trained to minimize the RL agent ’s cost of completing the sequence in each layer from top to bottom layers, which gradually increases the sub-tasks and thus forms an easy - to hard curriculum for the planner. Next, a bottom - up traversal of the tree trains the agent from easier sub -tasks with denser rewards on bottom layers to harder ones on top layers and collects its cost on each sub -task train the planner in the next episode.

This paper proposes a Bayesian framework for generating local explanations along with their associated uncertainty. The Bayesian version of LIME and KernelSHAP output credible intervals for the feature importances, capturing the associated uncertainty, and can be used to estimate the values of critical hyperparameters ( e.g., the number of perturbations needed to generate explanations with a desired level of uncertainty ). The paper also proposes a novel sampling technique called focused sampling that leverages the uncertainty estimates to determine how to sample perturbation for faster convergence. Experimental evaluation with multiple real world datasets and user studies demonstrate the efficacy of the proposed framework.

This paper studies the problem of unordered heavy tails in adversarial neural networks ( ANNs ). The authors argue that the heavy - tails in ANNs could lead to worse classification and propose to pre - define ANN features to follow a mixture of Multivariate Skew Laplace distributions, with which the heavy tails can be better controlled with high order moment skewness. They introduce an angle - based constraint on distribution parameters to incorporate high diversity of distribution tails in angle space so that the overlapping can be eliminated. Experiments conducted on several benchmarks and comparison with other distributions demonstrate the effectiveness of proposed approach for boosting the performance of ANNs.

This paper studies the phenomenon of gradient starvation in neural networks. The authors formalize gradient starvation as a phenomenon that arises when the cross - entropy loss is minimized by capturing only a subset of features relevant for the task, despite the presence of other predictive features that fail to be discovered. They provide a theoretical explanation for the emergence of such feature imbalances in neural network training. They identify simple properties of learning dynamics during gradient descent that lead to this imbalance and prove that such a situation can be expected given certain statistical structure in training data. Based on their proposed formalism, they develop a novel regularization method aimed at decoupling feature learning dynamics, improving accuracy and robustness in cases hindered by gradient starvation.

This paper presents a single - blind evaluation of teams of humans and AI agents in the cooperative card game Hanabi, with both rule - based and learning - based agents. In addition to the game score, the authors also quantify subjective measures of the human ’s perceived performance, teamwork, interpretability, trust, and overall preference of AI teammate. They find that humans have a clear preference toward a rule -based AI teammate ( SmartBot ) over a state - of - the - art learning - baselines ( Other - Play ) across nearly all subjective metrics, and generally view the learning based agent negatively, despite no statistical difference in the game scores.

This paper presents a novel approach for visual question generation ( VQG ), where the goal is to generate human - like neural questions from an image and potentially other side information ( e.g., answer type or the answer itself ). The key idea is to use double visual and answer hints to generate high - quality questions. The proposed method consists of a double - hint - based question generator and a question - answer - aware discriminator. The discriminator is to distinguish whether a sample triplet ( i.e., the image, answer, and question ) is generated from the generator or ground truth.

This paper proposes a method to mitigate label noise and class imbalance by manipulating gradients at the class level. To do so, it unrolls the loss gradient to class - level gradients by the chain rule and reweights the flow of each gradient separately. The proposed method achieves remarkable performance improvement on both issues. Extensive experiments in various settings verify the effectiveness of GDW.

This paper presents a method for learning spatio - temporal language grounding. The method is based on a synthetic language, where the goal is to learn a truth function that predicts if a given description matches a given history of observations. The descriptions involve time - extended predicates in past and present tense as well as spatiotemporal references to objects in the scene. The authors train several models including multimodal Transformer architectures. The latter implement different attention computations between words and objects across space and time. They test models on two classes of generalization : 1 ) generalization to randomly held - out sentences ; 2 ) generalizing to grammar primitives.

This paper proposes a new method for multiple object tracking and segmentation in video. The proposed method is based on a cross - attention network, which first distills the space - time memory into a set of prototypes and then uses the prototypes to retrieve rich information from the past frames. To segment each object, PCAN adopts a prototypical appearance module to learn contrastive foreground and background prototypes, which are then propagated over time. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies whether gradient flow can be used to represent gradient descent in deep learning. In particular, the authors consider gradient flow as an approximate numerical solution to the initial value problem of gradient flow. They show that the degree of approximation depends on the curvature around the gradient flow trajectory. They then show that over deep neural networks with homogeneous activations, gradient flow trajectories enjoy favorable curvature, suggesting they are well approximated by gradient descent.

This paper studies a stochastic multi - armed bandit problem with delayed impact of actions. In the bandit setting, actions taken in the past impact the arm rewards in the future. The paper proposes an algorithm that achieves a regret of $ \Omega(\sqrt{2/3})$ and a matching regret lower bound of $ O(KT 2/3)$, where $ K$ is the number of arms and T is the learning horizon.

This paper proposes a novel method for video instance segmentation based on transformers. The authors propose to utilize concise memory tokens as a means of conveying information as well as summarizing each frame scene. The features of each frame are enriched and correlated with other frames through exchange of information between the precisely encoded memory tokens. They validate their method on the latest benchmark sets and achieve state - of - the - art performance ( AP 42.6 on YouTube - VIS 2019 val set using the offline inference ) while having a considerably fast runtime ( 89.4 FPS ).

This paper proposes a method to mitigate the bias of random walks in graph embedding based on the degree of each node in a graph. Specifically, the authors argue that random walks can be biased due to the structural properties of graphs. The authors propose residual2vec, a method that can debias various structural biases in graphs by using random graphs. They show that this debiasing not only improves link prediction and clustering performance but also allows us to explicitly model salient structural properties.

This paper studies the problem of estimating non - linear functionals of discrete distributions in the context of local differential privacy. The initial data x1,..., xn are supposed to be i.i.d. and distributed according to an unknown discrete distribution p = ( p1,..., pK ). Only α - locally differentially private ( LDP ) samples z1,..., zn are publicly available, where the term ’ local ’ means that each zi is produced using one individual attribute xi.   The paper describes privacy mechanisms ( PM ) that are sequentially interactive ( i.e. they are allowed to use already published confidential data ) or non - interactive ( they can use publicly available data ). The paper also describes the behavior of the quadratic risk for estimating the power sum functional Fγ = \sum_{k=1 p \� k, \� > 0 as a function of K, n and α.

This paper studies the problem of online multiclass classification in the setting where the learner ’s feedback is determined by an arbitrary directed graph. The authors introduce a new algorithm, GAPPLETRON, that works with arbitrary feedback graphs. They prove surrogate regret bounds that hold, both in expectation and with high probability, for a large class of surrogate losses. They also prove a general lower bound of order max { BK, T } showing that their upper bounds are not significantly improvable.

This paper studies the problem of explainable clustering in the setting first formalized by Dasgupta, Frost, Moshkovitz, and Rashtchian ( ICML 2020 ). A k - clustering is said to be explainable if it is given by a decision tree where each internal node splits data points with a threshold cut in a single dimension ( feature ), and each of the k leaves corresponds to a cluster. The authors give an algorithm that outputs an explainable cluster that loses at most a factor of O(log k ) compared to an optimal ( not necessarily explainable ) clustering for the k - medians objective, and O(k log k ) for k - means objective. The algorithm is remarkably simple.

This paper proposes a multilingual pre - trained language model ( PrLM ) that uses the universal dependency parses as a pre - training objective and a representation for downstream NLP tasks. The model is evaluated on two cross - lingual NLP benchmarks ( XNLI and XQuAD ) and four syntactic parsing datasets ( UD2 v2.7, SPMRL’14, English Penn Treebank ( PTB ), CTCB 5.1 ). The proposed model outperforms two popular multilingual PrLMs, multilingual - BERT and XLM - R, on all three tasks.

This paper presents a novel Dual - Aspect Collaborative Transformer ( DACT ) to learn embeddings for the node and positional features separately, instead of fusing them together as done in existing ones, so as to avoid potential noises and incompatible correlations. The positional features are embedded through a novel cyclic positional encoding ( CPE ) method to capture the circularity and symmetry of VRP solutions ( i.e., cyclic sequences ). The proposed method is applied to solve the traveling salesman problem ( TSP ) and capacitated vehicle routing problem ( CVRP ).

This paper proposes a method to compute the exact Bayes error of generative models learned using normalizing flows. The method is based on the invertible transformation of the Bayes errors of the learned flow models by computing them for Gaussian base distributions, which can be done efficiently using Holmes - Diaconis - Ross integration. The authors show that by varying the temperature of the models, they can generate synthetic datasets that closely resemble standard benchmark datasets, but with almost any desired Bayesian error. They use their approach to conduct a thorough investigation of state - of - the - art classification models, and find that in some cases, these models are capable of obtaining accuracy very near optimal.

This paper proposes a new method for initializing neural networks. The proposed method is based on a simple heuristic : the norm of each network layer is adjusted so that a single step of SGD or Adam with prescribed hyperparameters results in the smallest possible loss value. This adjustment is done by introducing a scalar multiplier variable in front of each parameter block, and then optimizing these variables using a simple numerical scheme. The authors show that the proposed method accelerates the convergence and test performance of many convolutional architectures.

This paper proposes a method to learn a Riemannian manifold for estimating the progression of a patient's disease progression using longitudinal data. The proposed method is based on learning the push - forward of the Euclidean metric by a diffeomorphism, which is estimated iteratively as the composition of radial basis functions belonging to a reproducible kernel Hilbert space. The method is evaluated on the Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative ( ADNI ) dataset and the TADPOLE challenge.

This paper proposes a routing - by - memory mechanism for existing CNN architectures. In each stage of the network, they introduce parallel Procedural Units ( PUs ). A PU consists of a memory head and a procedure. The memory head maintains a summary of a type of features. For an intermediate feature, we search its closest memory and forward it to the corresponding procedure in both training and testing.

This paper studies the problem of equivariance of non - linear O(d)-equivariant functions in terms of scalar products and scalar contractions of the scalar, vector, and tensor inputs. The authors show that it is possible to parametrize polynomial functions that are equivariant under the Euclidean, Lorentz, and Poincaré groups, at any dimension d. They also show that the symmetries considered in this work are all global symmetry, as they act on all points in the same way.

This paper proposes to generalize the Intersection over Union ( IoU ) loss and its variants to a new family of power IoU losses that have a power term and an additional power regularization term with a single power parameter. The authors analyze properties such as order preservingness and loss / gradient reweighting. They empirically show that the proposed loss can outperform existing IoU - based losses and provide more robustness for small datasets and noisy bboxes.

This paper studies the problem of distributionally robust imitation learning ( DROIL ). The authors show that DROIL can be seen as a framework that maximizes a generalized concept of entropy. They develop a novel approach to transform the objective function into a convex optimization problem over a polynomial number of variables for a class of loss functions that are additive over state and action spaces. They extend DROIL to both stationary and non - stationary policies and show the benefits of DROIL.

This paper studies post - processing algorithms for individual fairness in the setting of algorithmic fairness. In this setting, the learner only has access to the predictions of the original model and a similarity graph between individuals guiding the desired fairness constraints. The authors propose a graph smoothing problem corresponding to graph Laplacian regularization that preserves the desired “ treat similar individuals similarly ” interpretation. Theoretical results demonstrate the connection of the new objective function to a local relaxation of individual fairness. Empirically, the proposed algorithms correct individual biases in large - scale NLP models such as BERT.

This paper proposes a new model for the cross - domain Text - to - SQL task. The proposed model is based on the dual - graph model and the question - linking method to learn the mapping between words in the question and tables / columns in the database schemas. The authors propose a structure - aware aggregation method with global graph linking, local graph linking and DualGraph Aggregation Mechanism. The experimental results show that the proposed model outperforms the baseline methods and achieves 3rd place on the benchmark Spider 2.

This paper studies the problem of learning stochastic computation graphs with multiple discrete components. The authors show that it is challenging to optimize the parameters of these models, mainly due to small gradients and local minima. They then propose two new strategies to overcome these challenges. First, increasing the scale parameter of the Gumbel noise perturbations during training improves the learning behavior. Second, they propose dropout residual connections specifically tailored to stochastically, discrete - continuous computation graphs.

This paper studies the problem of Bayesian Bayesian inference in the presence of covariate shift. The authors show that Bayesian neural networks ( BNNs ) with high - fidelity approximate inference via full - batch Hamiltonian Monte Carlo achieve poor generalization under covariate shifts. They also show why the same issue does not affect many approximate inference procedures, or classical maximum a - posteriori ( MAP ) training. Finally, they propose novel priors that improve the robustness of BNN to many sources of covariances shift.

This paper categorizes meta few - shot learning evaluation into two settings : in - distribution ( ID ) and out - of distribution ( OOD ). In the ID setting, the training and test tasks are sampled iid from the same underlying task distribution, and in the OOD setting, they are not. The authors identify that most existing FSL benchmarks instead reflect OOD evaluation, as they use disjoint sets of train ( base ) and test ( novel ) classes for task generation. This discrepancy is problematic because meta - learning methods that perform better on existing OOD datasets may perform significantly worse in the ID settings. To address these concerns, the authors suggest new benchmarks to allow for ID evaluation as well as more reliable OOD evaluations.

This paper studies the problem of rule induction in the context of language model ( LM ) - based rule generation. The authors argue that the current LM - based methods are “ learning rules from rules ”, which limits these methods to only produce “ canned ” rules whose patterns are constrained by the annotated rules, while discarding the rich expressive power of LMs for free text. To this end, the authors propose the open rule induction problem, which aims to induce open rules utilizing the knowledge in LMs. Besides, they propose the Orion system to automatically mine open rules from LMs without supervision.

This paper proposes a novel offline RL algorithm, named Implicit Constraint Q - learning ( ICQ ), which effectively alleviates the extrapolation error by only trusting the state - action pairs given in the dataset for value estimation. Moreover, the proposed method extends ICQ to multi - agent tasks by decomposing the joint - policy under the implicit constraint. The proposed method is evaluated on the D4RL and StarCraft II offline tasks.

This paper proposes a method to generate non - uniform perturbations to improve adversarial robustness against evasion attacks. The proposed method is based on the observation that uniform norm - ball constraints do not result in realistic adversarial examples ( AEs ) in real - world applications, where features typically have some semantically meaningful dependencies. The authors propose using characteristics of the empirical data distribution, both on correlations between the features and the importance of the features themselves, as well as precomputed covariance matrix and Shapley values. They show that the proposed method achieves better robustness to adversarial attacks compared to uniform norms.

This paper studies the convergence of iterated Tikhonov regularization for generalized self - concordant loss functions ( GSC ). The main contribution of the paper is the convergence rate of the excess risk of the least square loss function. The authors show that the iterated version of the regularization can achieve faster convergence rates than the classical Tikh onov method. They also show that it is possible to compute the estimator in practice.

This paper proposes a new kind of linear transform named Deformable Butterfly ( DeBut ) that generalizes the conventional butterfly matrices and can be adapted to various input - output dimensions. It inherits the fine - to - coarse - grained learnable hierarchy of traditional butterflies and when deployed to neural networks, the prominent structures and sparsity in a DeBut layer constitutes a new way for network compression. Experiments demonstrate its superiority in homogenizing a neural network and rendering it favorable properties such as light weight and low inference complexity, without compromising accuracy.

This paper proposes MetA Reusable Knowledge ( MARK ), a method to address the problem of catastrophic forgetting ( CF ) in continual learning. The proposed method is based on the construction and query of a common Knowledge Base ( KB ) that uses metalearning to incrementally accumulate relevant knowledge from different tasks. Experiments show that the proposed method achieves state of the art results in both 20 - Split CIFAR-100 and 20-Split MiniImageNet, while suffering almost no forgetfulness.

This paper proposes a data - driven framework for scheduling primal heuristics in exact MIP solvers. The proposed method learns a schedule of primal heuristic schedules that collectively find many solutions at minimal cost. The authors show that the proposed method is able to reduce the average primal integral by up to 49 % on two classes of challenging instances.

This paper studies the problem of reinforcement learning in which the learner receives binary feedback only once at the end of an episode. The authors study the case where trajectory labels are generated by an unknown parametric model, and provide a statistically and computationally efficient algorithm that achieves sublinear regret. Under an explorability assumption, the authors show that their algorithm is computationally and statistically efficient.

This paper proposes a novel method to represent edges of a graph using a dual hypergraph. The authors propose a message - passing scheme for node representation learning and edge representation learning based on Dual Hypergraph Transformation ( DHT ). They also propose two edge pooling methods to obtain a holistic edge representation for a given graph, where one clusters similar edges into a single edge for graph reconstruction and the other drops unnecessary edges for graph classification. They validate the proposed method on graph reconstruction, generation, and classification tasks.

This paper studies the sufficiency of a state representation for learning and representing the optimal policy in the context of reinforcement learning ( RL ). In particular, the authors study two popular MI - based objectives : mutual information maximization ( MI ) maximization and mutual information minimization ( MIM ). They show that two of these objectives can yield insufficient representations given mild and common assumptions on the structure of the MDP. They also provide a formal framework to analyze newly proposed representation learning objectives based on MI.

This paper proposes a novel method for steerable convolution for 3D object semantic analysis. The proposed method is based on steerable tensors. The authors propose a feature - steering module that takes the full advantage of SE(3)-equivariance and is able to conduct an efficient pose refinement. Experiments are conducted on three tasks of pose estimation, category - level 6D pose estimation and size estimation, and category level 6d pose tracking.

This paper proposes a dynamic token sparsification framework to prune redundant tokens progressively and dynamically based on the input. The proposed method is based on a lightweight prediction module to estimate the importance score of each token given the current features. To optimize the prediction module in an end - to - end manner, the authors propose an attention masking strategy to differentiably prune a token by blocking its interactions with other tokens. The experimental results demonstrate the competitive trade - off between speed and accuracy.

This paper studies the problem of distribution - free inference on the conditional mean E [ Y | X ]. In particular, the authors consider the setting where the features X are continuously distributed, where the confidence interval for E [Y | X] must have non - vanishing width, even as sample size tends to infinity. In the other extreme, if X takes only a small number of possible values, then the authors study the problem in settings in between these two extremes. They find that there are several distinct regimes in between the finite setting and the continuous setting, where vanishing - width confidence intervals are achievable if and only if the effective support size of the distribution of X is smaller than the square of the sample size.

This paper proposes Representation Neutralization for Fairness ( RNF ), a method to reduce the discrimination of DNN models by only debiasing the classification head, even with biased representations as inputs. The proposed method leverages samples with the same ground truth label but different sensitive attributes, and use their neutralized representations to train the classification heads of the DNN model. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new type of convolutional layer that takes advantage of Bessel functions, well known in physics, to build Bessel - CNNs ( B - CNN ) that are invariant to all the continuous set of possible rotation angles by design. The proposed method is based on the idea that the Bessel function is discretely sampled on a grid, with a resolution fixed by the size of the filters. Experiments are conducted to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new large - scale solver for kernel ridge regression. The proposed method combines partitioning with random projections and iterative optimization to reduce space and time complexity while provably maintaining the same statistical accuracy. In particular, constructing suitable partitions directly in the feature space rather than in the input space, the proposed method promotes orthogonality between the local estimators, thus ensuring that key quantities such as local effective dimension and bias remain under control.

This paper proposes a method for learning to communicate among agents via discrete tokens. The proposed method is based on word embedding techniques from natural language processing. The authors show that the proposed method can learn to cluster tokens in semantically - meaningful ways, allowing them to communicate in noisy environments where other techniques fail. They also show that agents using their method can effectively respond to novel human communication and that humans can understand unlabeled emergent agent communication.

This paper proposes a new family of hybrid models named CoAtNets to combine the strengths of convolutional and transformer architectures. The proposed method is based on the observation that depthwise convolution and self - attention can be unified via simple relative attention, and vertically stacking convolution layers and attention layers in a principled way is surprisingly effective in improving generalization, capacity and efficiency. Experiments show that the proposed method achieves state - of - the - art performance under different resource constraints across various datasets.

The paper presents a new second - order oracle bound for the expected risk of a weighted majority vote. The bound is based on a novel parametric form of the ChebyshevCantelli inequality, which is amenable to efficient minimization. The paper also derives a new concentration of measure inequality which combines PAC - Bayesian bounding with Bennett ’s inequality.

This paper proposes a weakly supervised method for audio - visual video parsing. The proposed method leverages both the common and diverse event semantics across videos to identify audio or visual events. In addition, the proposed method explores event co - occurrence across audio, visual, and audio - video streams. The discovered supervisory signals across different videos and modalities can greatly facilitate the training with only video - level annotations. Extensive experimental results show that the proposed approach substantially improves several baselines.

This paper proposes QuPeD, a federated learning algorithm for personalized and quantized model compression. The proposed algorithm is based on a relaxed optimization problem, where quantization values are also optimized over. In particular, the authors propose an alternating proximal gradient update for solving this compressed personalization problem, and analyze its convergence properties. Numerically, the proposed algorithm outperforms competing personalized FL methods and local training of clients in various heterogeneous settings.

This paper proposes a novel framework for constrained clustering based on variational auto - encoders ( VAE ). The proposed model ( DC - GMM ) uncovers the underlying distribution of data conditioned on prior clustering preferences, expressed as pairwise constraints. These constraints guide the clustering process towards a desirable partition of the data by indicating which samples should or should not belong to the same cluster. The authors conduct extensive experiments to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the problem of computing the Neural Tangent Kernel ( NTK ), which characterizes the behavior of infinitely - wide neural networks trained under least squares loss by gradient descent. The authors propose a near input - sparsity time approximation algorithm for NTK, by sketching the polynomial expansions of arc - cosine kernels. The sketch for the convolutional counterpart of NTK ( CNTK ) can transform any image using a linear runtime in the number of pixels. Furthermore, the authors prove a spectral approximation guarantee for the NTK matrix, by combining random features ( based on leverage score sampling ) of the arc - Cosine kernels with a sketching algorithm. They benchmark their methods on various large - scale regression and classification tasks.

This paper proposes a multi - person 3D motion trajectory prediction method based on multi - range Transformers. The proposed method is based on the observation that a human ’s action and behaviors may highly depend on the other persons around. The authors propose a Multi - Range Transformers model which contains of a local - range encoder for individual motion and a global - range decoder for social interactions. The model performs prediction for each person by taking a corresponding pose as a query which attends to both local and global-range encoder features. Experiments are conducted on CMU - Mocap, MuPoTS - 3D, 3DPW and Panoptic datasets.

This paper proposes a model predictive program synthesis ( MPPS ) approach to automatically generate guiding programs for long - horizon planning problems. The proposed approach trains a generative model to predict the unobserved portions of the world, and then synthesizes a program based on samples from this model in a way that is robust to its uncertainty. Experiments show that the proposed approach outperforms non - program - guided approaches on a set of challenging benchmarks, including a 2D Minecraft - inspired environment.

This paper studies the problem of causal imitation learning in the presence of a mismatch between a demonstrator and an imitator. The authors provide a graphical criterion that is necessary and sufficient for determining the feasibility of such imitation. They also provide an efficient algorithm for determining imitability and corroborate their theory with simulations.

This paper presents a slot - wise, object - based transition model that decomposes a scene into objects, aligns them ( with respect to a slotwise object memory ) to maintain a consistent order across time, and predicts how those objects evolve over successive frames. The model is trained end - to - end without supervision using transition losses at the level of the object - structured representation rather than pixels. The authors show that the combination of an objectlevel loss and correct object alignment over time enables the model to outperform a state - of - the - art baseline, and allows it to deal well with object occlusion and re - appearance in partially observable environments.

This paper studies the problem of off - policy risk minimization ( ERM ) in machine learning. The authors propose a generic importance sampling weighted ERM algorithm for using adaptively collected data to minimize the average of a loss function over a hypothesis class and provide first - of - their - kind generalization guarantees and fast convergence rates.    The authors show that their results are based on the new maximal inequality that carefully leverages the importance sampling structure to obtain rates with the good dependence on the exploration rate in the data. For regression, they provide fast rates that leverage the strong convexity of squared - error loss for policy learning. For policy learning, the authors provide regret guarantees that close an open gap in the existing literature whenever exploration decays to zero.

This paper proposes a novel and coherent scheme for kernel - reweighted regression by reparametrizing the sample weights using a doubly non - negative matrix. When the weighting matrix is confined in an uncertainty set using either the log - determinant divergence or the Bures - Wasserstein distance, the authors show that adversarially reweighting estimate can be solved efficiently using first - order methods. Numerical experiments show that the proposed scheme delivers promising results on numerous datasets.

This paper presents a method for training models with discrete latent variables. The authors propose to reparameterize categorical variables as sequences of binary variables and perform Rao - blackwellization. The proposed method is based on importance sampling and statistical couplings, which they extend to the categorical setting. Experiments show that the proposed method outperforms the state - of - the - art methods.

This paper proposes a new approach for predictive - based neural architecture search ( NAS ) based on a set of weak predictors. These predictors are trained to predict the sub - space of the best architecture. The paper proposes to use these predictors to guide the search towards the high - performance sub - spaces. The proposed approach is evaluated on NAS-Bench-101 and NAS - Bench-201 and shows better sample - efficiency compared to previous approaches.

This paper proposes a new method for intrinsic control based on the idea of maximizing the number of latent codes that can be discriminated from future states under some short time horizon ( e.g., in Montezuma ’s Revenge ). The proposed method is based on Entropic Desired Dynamics for Intrinsic ConTrol ( EDDICT ), which assumes fixed additive latent dynamics, which results in tractable learning and an interpretable latent space. Compared to prior methods, the proposed method allows it to be far more exploratory, as demonstrated by improved state coverage and increased unsupervised performance on hard exploration games such as Montezum's Revenge.

This paper proposes a novel framework for generating pharmacochemically acceptable molecules with large docking scores. The proposed method is based on fragment - based generative RL with Explorative Experience replay for Drug design ( FREED ). It constrains the generated molecules to a realistic and qualified chemical space and effectively explores the space to find drugs by coupling the fragment-based generation method and a novel error - prioritized experience replay ( PER ). The model produces molecules of higher quality compared to existing methods while achieving state - of - the - art performance on two of three targets in terms of the docking scores of generated molecules.

This paper studies the problem of learning directed acyclic graphical models from observational data in general settings without specific distributional assumptions. The proposed approach is information - theoretic and uses a local Markov boundary search procedure in order to recursively construct ancestral sets in the underlying graphical model. The authors show that for certain graph ensembles, a simple forward greedy search algorithm ( i.e. without a backward pruning phase ) suffices to learn the Markov boundaries of each node. This substantially improves the sample complexity, which is at most polynomial in the number of nodes. This is then applied to learning the entire graph under a novel identifiability condition that generalizes existing conditions from the literature.

This paper studies the problem of learning with differential privacy in the setting where each user holds m samples and the privacy protection is enforced at the level of each user ’s data. The authors show that, as long as each user receives sufficiently many samples, we can learn any privately learnable class via an ( ", " )DP algorithm using only O(log(1/\sqrt(1 / ) / ) users ).   The main contribution of the paper is a generalization of global stability that allows the use of public randomness. Under this relaxed notion, correlated sampling strategy is used to show that the global stability can be boosted to be arbitrarily close to one, at a polynomial expense in the number of samples. In both cases, the authors show a nearly - matching lower bound on number of users required.

This paper studies the effect of implicit representations of value functions on the convergence of stochastic gradient descent ( SGD ) in the context of reinforcement learning. In particular, the authors consider the case where the value function is parameterized by an implicit parameterization of a linear function. The authors show that the implicit representation leads to a non - linear and non - convex optimization problem, but the implicit linear weights still converge to a global optimum. Furthermore, they provide convergence rates for both cases which allow them to identify conditions under which the implicit parameterized parameterization exhibits a significantly faster convergence rate than its explicit counterpart.

This paper proposes a method for knowledge graph ( KG ) refinement. The proposed method is based on a combination of two existing methods for KG refinement : PSL - KGI and type - supervised KG embedding. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms the other two methods in terms of noise removal and new fact prediction.

This paper proposes a novel evaluation paradigm for knowledge base completion ( KB ) methods. The authors propose to use a data set FB14k - QAQ with an alternative evaluation data structure : instead of single facts, they use KB queries, i.e., facts where one entity is replaced with a variable, and construct corresponding sets of entities that are correct answers. They randomly remove some of these correct answers from the data set, simulating the realistic scenario of real - world entities missing from a KB. They evaluate a number of state - of - the - art KB embeddings models on the new benchmark.
