( 2016 ) ), which maximizes an agent ’s ‘ empowerment ’ and formulate a sandwich bound on the empowerment objective that allows identification of decision states. Unlike previous work, the decision states are discovered without extrinsic rewards – simply by interacting with the world. The results show that the proposed method leads to better exploration on downstream goal - driven tasks.

This paper proposes a novel framework for classifying irregularly sampled time series with unaligned measurements, focusing on high scalability and data efficiency. The proposed method SEFT ( Set Functions for Time Series ) is based on recent advances in differentiable set function learning, extremely parallelizable, and scales well to very large datasets and online monitoring scenarios. The authors extensively compare their method to competitors on multiple healthcare time series datasets and show that it performs competitively while significantly reducing runtime.

This paper proposes a method to model audio signal priors by explicitly utilizing the harmonic structure in audio signals. The method is based on the fact that convolutional kernels should be supported by sets of harmonic series, instead of by local neighborhoods. The proposed method is evaluated on unsupervised audio restoration tasks and supervised musical source separation tasks. The results show that the proposed method outperforms the baselines.

This paper proposes to use data echoing to reduce the total computation used by earlier pipeline stages and speed up training whenever computation upstream from accelerators dominates the training time. Data echoing reuses ( or “ ” “ Echoes ” ) intermediate outputs from earlier pipeline stage in order to reclaim idle capacity. The authors investigate the behavior of different data echoing algorithms on various workloads, for various amounts of echoing, and for various batch sizes. They find that in all settings, at least one data echoing algorithm can match the baseline ’s predictive performance using less upstream computation.

This paper proposes a new method for learning policies that are distinguishable from other policies in a Markov decision process ( MDP ). The proposed method is based on the idea of successor features, which is an extension of the successor features framework proposed by Barreto et al. ( 2017 ). In this paper, the authors propose a new algorithm, Variational Intrinsic Successor FeatuRes ( VISR ), which learns controllable features that can be leveraged to provide enhanced generalization and fast task inference through the successor feature framework. Experiments on the full Atari suite demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the generalization properties of deep neural networks in the overparameterized regime. The authors show that generalization results from smoothness of the functional approximation, combined with a flat initial approximation. This smoothness increases with number of units, explaining why massively overparametrized networks continue to generalize well. In particular, the global, rather than local, impact of breakpoints and delta - slope helps regularize the approximating function in the large gaps between training data, resulting in their smoothness.

This paper proposes a GAN - based approach for image - to - image translation based on attention mechanism. The idea is to augment the discriminator with an attention mechanism so that it estimates the probability that its input is real, and also does it create an attention map that highlights the critical features for such prediction. This attention map then assists the generator to produce more plausible and realistic images. The proposed approach is evaluated on a number of image transfer tasks.

This paper studies the role of multiplicative interaction as a unifying framework to describe a range of classical and modern neural network architectural motifs, such as gating, attention layers, hypernetworks, and dynamic convolutions. The authors conjecture that multiplicative interactions offer a particularly powerful inductive bias when fusing multiple streams of information or when conditional computation is required. They argue that they should be considered in many situation where multiple compute or information paths need to be combined, in place of the simple and oft - used concatenation operation.

This paper proposes a new algorithm for batch active learning with deep neural network models. The proposed algorithm samples groups of points that are disparate and high magnitude when represented in a hallucinated gradient space, a strategy designed to incorporate both predictive uncertainty and sample diversity into every selected batch. Crucially, the proposed algorithm trades off between uncertainty and diversity without requiring any hand - tuning hyperparameters. Experiments show that the proposed method is robust to architecture choice, batch size, and dataset.

This paper proposes a novel feature leveling architecture to improve the interpretability of self - explainable deep neural networks ( DNNs ). The proposed method is based on the idea of feature leveling, which is a method of separating low - level and high - level features in a DNN. The authors show that the proposed method can achieve competitive performance on standard datasets while being more interpretable.

This paper proposes a method for training a classifier over a large number of classes, known as ‘ extreme classification ’. The proposed method is based on a scalable approximation to the softmax loss function via a generalized form of negative sampling. By generating adversarial negative samples from an auxiliary model, the authors show that they maximize the signal - to - noise ratio of the stochastic gradient estimate. The authors further show that, while the auxiliary model introduces a bias, it can be removed at test time.

This paper presents a new approach for efficient exploration that leverages a low - dimensional encoding of the environment learned with a combination of model - based and model - free objectives. The proposed approach uses intrinsic rewards that are based on a weighted distance of nearest neighbors in the low dimensional representational space to gauge novelty, and leverage these intrinsic rewards for sample - efficient exploration with planning routines in representational spaces. The authors test their approach on a number of maze tasks, as well as a control problem and show that their exploration approach is more sample - inefficient compared to strong baselines.

This paper studies out - of - distribution detection in the few - shot setting. The authors propose two new methods for this task and investigate their performance. They show that existing confidence scores developed in the supervised setting ( i.e., setting with a fixed number of classes ) are not suitable when used with popular few-shot classifiers. Their proposed confidence scores, - MinDist and LCBO, substantially outperform the baselines on both tasks across four staple few - shots classification datasets.

This paper proposes a generalized model of sequence generation that unifies decoding in directed and undirected models. The proposed framework models the process of generation rather than a resulting sequence, and under this framework, the authors derive various neural sequence models as special cases, such as autoregressive, semi - auto - progressive, and refinement - based non - Autoregressive models. This unification enables the authors to adapt decoding algorithms originally developed for directed sequence models to the unsupervised setting. The authors evaluate the proposed approach on WMT’14 En - De machine translation using a recently proposed masked translation model.

This paper proposes a two - stage approach for the recognition of mathematical expressions ( MEs ). The first stage uses object detection to detect the mathematical symbols of the input image by object detection algorithm. The second stage uses a seq2seq model equipped with attention mechanism to generate the LaTeX sequence as output. The experimental results show that the proposed method outperforms the end - to - end method in terms of ExpRate.

This paper proposes a vector quantization method to reduce the memory footprint of convolutional neural networks. The proposed method is based on product quantization, which aims at preserving the quality of the reconstruction of the network outputs rather than its weights. The method only requires a set of unlabelled data at quantization time and allows for efficient inference on CPU by using bytealigned codebooks to store the compressed weights. Empirical results show that the proposed method leads to a 5 MB memory footprint and a 76.1 % top - 1 accuracy on ImageNet object classification.

This paper proposes a new model for the Transformer architecture. The proposed model is based on the Tensor - Product Transformer ( TP - Transformer ), which encodes the relations between each Transformer cell and the other cells from which values have been retrieved by attention. The model is evaluated on the recently introduced Mathematics Dataset containing 56 categories of free - form math wordproblems. It is shown that the proposed model outperforms the previous state - of - the - art by 8.24 %.

This paper studies the problem of generalization in deep learning. The authors derive a necessary and sufficient condition for generalization using a universal cognitive similarity metric, namely information distance, based on Kolmogorov complexity. They then formulate an optimization problem to learn a more general classification function by extending the input features by concatenating encodings of them, and then train the classifier on the extended features. Experiments demonstrate that a model trained on arbitrarily encoded input features is more robust to common corruptions and adversarial perturbations.

This paper proposes a new graph pooling operation based on compressive Haar transforms, called HaarPooling. It is computed by following a chain of sequential clusterings of the input graph. The input of each pooling layer is transformed by the compressed Haar basis of the corresponding clustering. It operates in the frequency domain by the synthesis of nodes in the same cluster and filters out fine detail information.

This paper proposes a new method for point cloud decoders. The proposed method is based on sample - based point - cloud decoder architectures that map a shape representation to a point feature distribution, allowing an arbitrary number of sampled features to be transformed into individual output points. The method is evaluated on three different architectures, and the authors show that it is competitive with or outperforms the MLP approach while using fewer parameters.

This paper presents a benchmark of real - world noisy labels at 10 controlled noise levels. The authors conduct a large - scale study across a variety of noise levels and types, architectures, methods, and training settings. They show that deep neural networks ( DNNs ) generalize much better on real world noise. They also show that when networks are fine - tuned, ImageNet architectures generalize well on noisy data. Finally, they show that robust learning methods that work well on synthetic noise may not work as well on real data and vice versa.

This paper proposes a new method for learning from rule - level supervision in the form of rules. The proposed method is based on the idea of combining the efficiency of rules with the quality of instance labels. The supervision is coupled such that it is both natural for humans and synergistic for learning. The training algorithm jointly denoises rules via latent coverage variables, and trains the model through a soft implication loss over the coverage and label variables.

This paper proposes a memory - based GNN ( MemGNN ) and graph memory network ( GMN ) to learn hierarchical graph representations for graph classification and regression tasks. The proposed models achieve state - of - the - art results in eight out of nine benchmark datasets. The authors also show that the learned representations could correspond to chemical features in the molecule data.

This paper studies the effect of initialization in deep linear networks on the convergence time of gradient descent. The authors provide a rigorous proof that drawing the initial weights from the orthogonal group speeds up convergence relative to the standard Gaussian initialization with iid weights. They show that for deep networks, the width needed for efficient convergence to a global minimum with orthogonality is independent of the depth. The width needed with Gaussian initializations scales linearly in depth.

This paper studies the problem of how to optimize the bit allocation of weights and activations for deep CNNs compression. The authors propose a Lagrangian - based method to solve the optimization problem via Lagrangians. The proposed method obtains excellent results on deep neural networks. It can compress deep CNN ResNet-50 down to 2 bits with only 0.7 % accuracy loss.

This paper proposes a new method for generative adversarial networks ( GANs ). The proposed method is based on the Wasserstein distance between the two - player training of WGANs. The authors propose an iterative primal dual optimization process to learn an encoder network and a generative network jointly. They also provide a probabilistic interpretation of their model under the framework of maximum likelihood estimation.

This paper proposes an extension of the mention pair model of anaphoric annotation ( MPA ) to alleviate the effects of sparsity inherent in some crowdsourcing environments. Specifically, the authors propose a nonparametric partially pooled structure ( based on a stick breaking process ), fitting jointly with the ability of the annotators hierarchical community profiles. The individual estimates can thus be improved using information about the community when the data is scarce. The authors show that the proposed model performs better than its unpooled counterpart in the case of low sparsity and on par when enough observations are available.

This paper proposes a new method for sparse reward reinforcement learning with intrinsic and extrinsic reward signals. The intrinsic reward signal is used to encourage the agent to explore the environment, while the extrinsics are used to reward the agent for completing the task. The authors propose a hierarchical intrinsic drive ( SID ) and successor feature control ( SFC ), which is general and not task - specific. The proposed method is evaluated in three different environments with pure visual inputs.

This paper proposes a method for weakly - supervised video moment retrieval, where the goal is to locate the video segment which is described by the sentence without having access to temporal annotations during training. The proposed method leverages a frame - by - word interaction module as well as a Word - conditioned visual graph ( WCVG ) to learn the latent correspondence between visual and language representations. Experiments on the DiDeMo and Charades - STA datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the learned representations.

This paper proposes a novel method for image - guided re - rendering of reconstructed objects. The proposed method is based on image - based rendering and GAN - based image synthesis. The main contribution of this paper is the handling of view - dependent effects. Specifically, the authors propose EffectsNet, a deep neural network that predicts view -dependent effects. Based on these estimations, they are able to convert observed images to diffuse images, which can be projected into other views. In the target view, the pipeline reinserts the new view - related effects.

This paper presents a sparse representation of model uncertainty for deep neural networks ( DNNs ) that relies on an inverse formulation of Multivariate Normal Distribution ( MND ), an information form. The authors show that the model uncertainty can be estimated in this form using a scalable Laplace Approximation scheme, which involves a diagonal correction of the Kronecker - factorized eigenbasis. They further devise a novel low - rank approximation of this eigenbais that exploits spectral sparsity of DNN.

This paper proposes a new method for min - wise hashing, called Amortization Hashing ( AHash ), which can generate as few empty bins as possible. The authors claim that the proposed method is more load - balanced and accurate without hurting runtime efficiency compared with the state - of - the - art OPH and densification strategies. Experiments on real datasets validate the claim.

This paper proposes a method for extracting features from phase shift data by adding a graph structure to each data point and constructing a suitable machine learning architecture for graph data with cyclic permutation to a graph neural network. The paper shows that adding a certain structure to data is shown to be very effective for feature extraction.

This paper proposes a new method for conditional text generation based on a confidence score, which is learned in training using a variational Bayes objective, and can be leveraged at inference time using a calibration technique to promote more faithful generation. Experiments on a structured data - to - text dataset – WikiBio ( Lebre et al. 2016 ) – show that the proposed method is more faithful to the source than existing state - of - the - art approaches.

This paper proposes a lookahead pruning method for pruning neural networks. The proposed method is based on the observation that magnitude - based pruning indeed minimizes the Frobenius distortion of a linear operator corresponding to a single layer operation. Based on this observation, the authors propose a simple pruning algorithm by extending the single layer optimization to a multi - layer optimization. The experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method consistently outperforms magnitude - pruning on various networks.

This paper proposes Moniqua, a decentralized stochastic gradient descent algorithm that uses quantized communication to communicate a provably bounded number of bits per iteration, while converging at the same asymptotic rate as the original algorithm does with full - precision communication.   Theoretically, the authors prove in theory that the proposed algorithm can communicate a bound on the number of bit per iteration. Empirically, it is shown that it converges faster with respect to wall clock time than other quantized decentralized algorithms. The authors also show that it is robust to very low bit - budgets.

This paper studies the problem of causally incorrect partial models in reinforcement learning. The authors show that partial models can be confounded by the observations they don’t model, and can therefore lead to incorrect planning. To address this, they introduce a general family of partial models that are provably causally correct, yet remain fast because they do not need to fully model future observations. They also propose a simple modification to partial models so that they can still make correct predictions under changes in the behavior policy.

This paper proposes a VAE model that learns a succinct representation of two correlated data variables for conditional and joint generation tasks. The model is based on two information theoretic problems, distributed simulation and channel synthesis, in which Wyner ’s common information arises as the fundamental limit of the succinctness of the common representation. The proposed model decomposes a pair of correlated variables into their common representation and local representations that capture the remaining randomness ( e.g., texture and style ) in respective data variables by imposing the mutual information between the data variables and common representation as a regularization term. The utility of the proposed approach is demonstrated through experiments for joint and conditional generation with and without style control using synthetic data and real images.
